A. de Jong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen, PO Box 800, 9700 AV Groningen, The Netherlands\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Konrad Kuijken\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Leiden Observatory, Leiden University, PO Box 9513, 2300 RA Leiden, The Netherlands\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Mario Radovich\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astronomico di Padova, Via dell\u2019Osservatorio 5, 35122 Padova, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"HuanYuan Shan\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Shanghai Astronomical Observatory (SHAO), Nandan Road 80, Shanghai 200030, PR China\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Valery Shulga\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"College of Physics of Jilin University, Qianjin Street 2699, Changchun 130012, PR China\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Institute of Radio Astronomy of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 4 Mystetstv Str., Kharkiv, Ukraine\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"KiDS-SQuaD - II. Machine learning selection of bright extragalactic objects to search for new gravitationally lensed quasars\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2019/11/27\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2019/12/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"632\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A56\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2019A%26A...632A..56K\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2019/12/aa36006-19.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"methods: data analysis\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"surveys\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"catalogs\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"quasars: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; The KiDS Strongly lensed QUAsar Detection project (KiDS-SQuaD) is aimed at finding as many previously undiscovered gravitational lensed quasars as possible in the Kilo Degree Survey. This is the second paper of this series where we present a new, automatic object-classification method based on the machine learning technique.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; The main goal of this paper is to build a catalogue of bright extragalactic objects (galaxies and quasars) from the KiDS Data Release 4, with minimum stellar contamination and preserving the completeness as much as possible. We show here that this catalogue represents the perfect starting point to search for reliable gravitationally lensed quasar candidates.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; After testing some of the most used machine learning algorithms, decision-tree-based classifiers, we decided to use CatBoost, which was specifically trained with the aim of creating a sample of extragalactic sources that is as clean of stars as possible. We discuss the input data, define the training sample for the classifier, give quantitative estimates of its performances, and finally describe the validation results with &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2, AllWISE, and GAMA catalogues.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; We built and made available to the scientific community the KiDS Bright EXtraGalactic Objects catalogue (KiDS-BEXGO), specifically created to find gravitational lenses but applicable to a wide number of scientific purposes. The KiDS-BEXGO catalogue is made of \u22486 million sources classified as quasars (\u2248200\u2006000) and galaxies (\u22485.7 M) up to &lt;i&gt;r&lt;i/&gt;\u2004&lt; \u200422&lt;sup&gt;m&lt;sup/&gt;. To demonstrate the potential of the catalogue in the search for strongly lensed quasars, we selected \u2248950 \u201cMultiplets\u201d: close pairs of quasars or galaxies surrounded by at least one quasar. We present cutouts and coordinates of the 12 most reliable gravitationally lensed quasar candidates. We showed that employing a machine learning method decreases the stellar contaminants within the gravitationally lensed candidates, comparing the current results to the previous ones, presented in the first paper from this series.&lt;i&gt;Conclusions.&lt;i/&gt; Our work presents the first comprehensive identification of bright extragalactic objects in KiDS DR4 data, which is, for us, the first necessary step towards finding strong gravitational lenses in wide-sky photometric surveys, but has also many other more general astrophysical applications.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=B. type=\"text/javascript\">\n\tjQuery(function ($) {\n\t    var source = function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div class=\"wrap\">                                  </div>                  \n data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico N. N. Karazin Kharkiv National University, 35 Sumska Str., Kharkiv, Ukraine\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Institute of Radio Astronomy of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 4 Mystetstv Str., Kharkiv, Ukraine\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Chiara Spiniello\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello, 16, 80131 Napoli, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"European Southern Observatory, Karl-Schwarschild-Str. 2, 85748 Garching, Germany\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Crescenzo Tortora\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astrofisico di Arcetri, Largo Enrico Fermi 5, 50125 Firenze, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Nicola R. Napolitano\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello, 16, 80131 Napoli, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"School of Physics and Astronomy, Sun Yat-sen University, 2 Daxue Road, Tangjia, Zhuhai, Guangdong 519082, PR China\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Adriano Agnello\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"DARK, Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen University, Lyngbyvej 2, 2100 Copenhagen, Denmark\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Fedor Getman\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello, 16, 80131 Napoli, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Jelte T. A. de Jong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen, PO Box 800, 9700 AV Groningen, The Netherlands\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Konrad Kuijken\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Leiden Observatory, Leiden University, PO Box 9513, 2300 RA Leiden, The Netherlands\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Mario Radovich\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astronomico di Padova, Via dell\u2019Osservatorio 5, 35122 Padova, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"HuanYuan Shan\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Shanghai Astronomical Observatory (SHAO), Nandan Road 80, Shanghai 200030, PR China\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Valery Shulga\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"College of Physics of Jilin University, Qianjin Street 2699, Changchun 130012, PR China\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Institute of Radio Astronomy of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 4 Mystetstv Str., Kharkiv, Ukraine\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"KiDS-SQuaD - II. Machine learning selection of bright extragalactic objects to search for new gravitationally lensed quasars\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2019/11/27\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2019/12/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"632\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A56\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2019A%26A...632A..56K\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2019/12/aa36006-19.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"methods: data analysis\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"surveys\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"catalogs\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"quasars: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; The KiDS Strongly lensed QUAsar Detection project (KiDS-SQuaD) is aimed at finding as many previously undiscovered gravitational lensed quasars as possible in the Kilo Degree Survey. This is the second paper of this series where we present a new, automatic object-classification method based on the machine learning technique.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; The main goal of this paper is to build a catalogue of bright extragalactic objects (galaxies and quasars) from the KiDS Data Release 4, with minimum stellar contamination and preserving the completeness as much as possible. We show here that this catalogue represents the perfect starting point to search for reliable gravitationally lensed quasar candidates.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; After testing some of the most used machine learning algorithms, decision-tree-based classifiers, we decided to use CatBoost, which was specifically trained with the aim of creating a sample of extragalactic sources that is as clean of stars as possible. We discuss the input data, define the training sample for the classifier, give quantitative estimates of its performances, and finally describe the validation results with &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2, AllWISE, and GAMA catalogues.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; We built and made available to the scientific community the KiDS Bright EXtraGalactic Objects catalogue (KiDS-BEXGO), specifically created to find gravitational lenses but applicable to a wide number of scientific purposes. The KiDS-BEXGO catalogue is made of \u22486 million sources classified as quasars (\u2248200\u2006000) and galaxies (\u22485.7 M) up to &lt;i&gt;r&lt;i/&gt;\u2004&lt; \u200422&lt;sup&gt;m&lt;sup/&gt;. To demonstrate the potential of the catalogue in the search for strongly lensed quasars, we selected \u2248950 \u201cMultiplets\u201d: close pairs of quasars or galaxies surrounded by at least one quasar. We present cutouts and coordinates of the 12 most reliable gravitationally lensed quasar candidates. We showed that employing a machine learning method decreases the stellar contaminants within the gravitationally lensed candidates, comparing the current results to the previous ones, presented in the first paper from this series.&lt;i&gt;Conclusions.&lt;i/&gt; Our work presents the first comprehensive identification of bright extragalactic objects in KiDS DR4 data, which is, for us, the first necessary step towards finding strong gravitational lenses in wide-sky photometric surveys, but has also many other more general astrophysical applications.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=B.             dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: <div class=\"history\">\n<p><b>Notes.</b> All of them are recovered in our extragalactic catalogue, 8 out of 17 have multiple matches. For the single ones (upper &#8220;block&#8221;), 5 out of 17 are classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt> and 4 out of 17 as <tt>QSO</tt>. For the multiple matches, half of the time all the components belong to the same family (middle &#8220;block&#8221;) and the other half of the time they belong to different families (bottom &#8220;block&#8221;). We report for each component of each system the J2000 coordinates in the ID column (in the usual &#8220;hhmmss.ss &#177; ddmmss.ss&#8221; format), and the probability of belonging to each of the three classification families, highlighting the highest probability in bold.</p>\n</div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" data-edps_ref=\"aa36006-19\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico ico-info\"></span>\n\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t<p>Initial download of the metrics may take a while.</p>\n\t\t</div>\n\t</div>\n\n\n</div>\n\n\n\n\n</div>\n<script type=\"text/javascript\" <meta name=\"citation_journal_title\" content=\"Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_journal_abbrev\" content=\"A&amp;A\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publisher\" content=\"EDP N. Karazin Kharkiv National University, 35 Sumska Str., Kharkiv, Ukraine\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Alexey Sergeyev\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Institute of Astronomy, V. N. Karazin Kharkiv National University, 35 Sumska Str., Kharkiv, Ukraine\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Institute of Radio Astronomy of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 4 Mystetstv Str., Kharkiv, Ukraine\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Chiara Spiniello\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello, 16, 80131 Napoli, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"European Southern Observatory, Karl-Schwarschild-Str. 2, 85748 Garching, Germany\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Crescenzo Tortora\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astrofisico di Arcetri, Largo Enrico Fermi 5, 50125 Firenze, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Nicola R. Napolitano\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello, 16, 80131 Napoli, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"School of Physics and Astronomy, Sun Yat-sen University, 2 Daxue Road, Tangjia, Zhuhai, Guangdong 519082, PR China\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Adriano Agnello\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"DARK, Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen University, Lyngbyvej 2, 2100 Copenhagen, Denmark\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Fedor Getman\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello, 16, 80131 Napoli, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Jelte T. A. de Jong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen, PO Box 800, 9700 AV Groningen, The Netherlands\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Konrad Kuijken\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Leiden Observatory, Leiden University, PO Box 9513, 2300 RA Leiden, The Netherlands\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Mario Radovich\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"INAF \u2013 Osservatorio Astronomico di Padova, Via dell\u2019Osservatorio 5, 35122 Padova, Italy\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"HuanYuan Shan\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Shanghai Astronomical Observatory (SHAO), Nandan Road 80, Shanghai 200030, PR China\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Valery Shulga\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"College of Physics of Jilin University, Qianjin Street 2699, Changchun 130012, PR China\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Institute of Radio Astronomy of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 4 Mystetstv Str., Kharkiv, Ukraine\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"KiDS-SQuaD - II. Machine learning selection of bright extragalactic objects to search for new gravitationally lensed quasars\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2019/11/27\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2019/12/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"632\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A56\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2019A%26A...632A..56K\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2019/12/aa36006-19.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"methods: data analysis\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"surveys\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"catalogs\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"quasars: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: general\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Context.&lt;i/&gt; The KiDS Strongly lensed QUAsar Detection project (KiDS-SQuaD) is aimed at finding as many previously undiscovered gravitational lensed quasars as possible in the Kilo Degree Survey. This is the second paper of this series where we present a new, automatic object-classification method based on the machine learning technique.&lt;i&gt;Aims.&lt;i/&gt; The main goal of this paper is to build a catalogue of bright extragalactic objects (galaxies and quasars) from the KiDS Data Release 4, with minimum stellar contamination and preserving the completeness as much as possible. We show here that this catalogue represents the perfect starting point to search for reliable gravitationally lensed quasar candidates.&lt;i&gt;Methods.&lt;i/&gt; After testing some of the most used machine learning algorithms, decision-tree-based classifiers, we decided to use CatBoost, which was specifically trained with the aim of creating a sample of extragalactic sources that is as clean of stars as possible. We discuss the input data, define the training sample for the classifier, give quantitative estimates of its performances, and finally describe the validation results with &lt;i&gt;Gaia&lt;i/&gt; DR2, AllWISE, and GAMA catalogues.&lt;i&gt;Results.&lt;i/&gt; We built and made available to the scientific community the KiDS Bright EXtraGalactic Objects catalogue (KiDS-BEXGO), specifically created to find gravitational lenses but applicable to a wide number of scientific purposes. The KiDS-BEXGO catalogue is made of \u22486 million sources classified as quasars (\u2248200\u2006000) and galaxies (\u22485.7 M) up to &lt;i&gt;r&lt;i/&gt;\u2004&lt; \u200422&lt;sup&gt;m&lt;sup/&gt;. To demonstrate the potential of the catalogue in the search for strongly lensed quasars, we selected \u2248950 \u201cMultiplets\u201d: close pairs of quasars or galaxies surrounded by at least one quasar. We present cutouts and coordinates of the 12 most reliable gravitationally lensed quasar candidates. We showed that employing a machine learning method decreases the stellar contaminants within the gravitationally lensed candidates, comparing the current results to the previous ones, presented in the first paper from this series.&lt;i&gt;Conclusions.&lt;i/&gt; Our work presents the first comprehensive identification of bright extragalactic objects in KiDS DR4 data, which is, for us, the first necessary step towards finding strong gravitational lenses in wide-sky photometric surveys, but has also many other more general astrophysical applications.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=B.             dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: to databases </a></li><li class=\"item-381\"><a href=\"/for-authors/latex-issues/latex-examples\" >LaTeX examples</a></li><li class=\"item-466\"><a href=\"/for-authors/latex-issues/information-files\"                     \n<div id=\"system-message-container\">\n</div>\n                      \n\n                      \n                                              <div class=\"flexme flexme-article\">\n                        <div class=\"article-content\">\n                                <div>\r\n    \n<div class=\"special_article green\">Free Access</div>\n    \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n \r\n    <div class=\"summary full\" >\n\t<table>\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\t<tr>\n\t\t<th valign=\"top\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tIssue\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t<td width=\"10\"></td>\n\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tA&A\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div><strong>Volume </strong>632, December 2019\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</td>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" ></td></tr>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" class=\"sep_issue\"></td></tr>\n\t</tr>\n\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tArticle Number\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>A56</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tNumber of page(s)\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>18</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Section</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>Catalogs and data</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>DOI</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\">\n\t\t\t\t\thttps://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\n\t\t\t\t</a>\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Published online</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t27 November 2019\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t</table>\n</div>\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"article\">\r\n    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\">\n\n<div class=\"menu\" id=\"bloc\"><ul>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#top_full\">Top</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#abs\">Abstract</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S1\">1. Introduction</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S2\">2. Data overview</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S5\">3. Classification</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S10\" title=\"The Bright EXtraGalactic Objects catalogue in KiDS DR4 (KiDS-BEXGO)\">4. The Bright ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S14\" title=\"Searching for gravitationally lensed quasars\">5. Searching for ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S18\">6. Results and conclusions</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#ack\">Acknowledgments</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#ref\">References</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#app\">Appendix A:</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#tabs\">List of tables</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#figs\">List of figures</a></li>\n</ul></div>\n<div id=\"contenu\">\n<a name=\"top_full\"></a><div id=\"head\">A&amp;A 632, A56 (2019)<h2 class=\"title\">KiDS-SQuaD</h2>\n<h3 class=\"subtitle\">II. Machine learning selection of bright extragalactic objects to search for new gravitationally lensed quasars<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN1\">&#8902;</a></sup>\n</h3>\n<div class=\"article-authors\"><p class=\"bold\"><span id=\"aa36006-19-author-1\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=1\" class=\"author\">Vladislav Khramtsov</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-2\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=2\" class=\"author\">Alexey Sergeyev</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,2</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-3\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=3\" class=\"author\">Chiara Spiniello</span><sup>3</sup><sup>,4</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-4\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=4\" class=\"author\">Crescenzo Tortora</span><sup>5</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-5\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=5\" class=\"author\">Nicola R. Napolitano</span><sup>3</sup><sup>,6</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-6\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=6\" class=\"author\">Adriano Agnello</span><sup>7</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-7\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=7\" class=\"author\">Fedor Getman</span><sup>3</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-8\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=8\" class=\"author\">Jelte T. A. de Jong</span><sup>8</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-9\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=9\" class=\"author\">Konrad Kuijken</span><sup>9</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-10\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=10\" class=\"author\">Mario Radovich</span><sup>10</sup>, <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-11\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=11\" class=\"author\">HuanYuan Shan</span><sup>11</sup> and <span id=\"aa36006-19-author-12\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006&amp;n=12\" class=\"author\">Valery Shulga</span><sup>12</sup><sup>,2</sup></p></div>\n<p class=\"aff\">\n<sup>1</sup> \n \nInstitute of Astronomy, V. N. Karazin Kharkiv National University, 35 Sumska Str.,  Kharkiv,  Ukraine \n \n\n<br>e-mail: vld.khramtsov@gmail.com<br>\n<sup>2</sup> \n \n Institute of Radio Astronomy of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, 4 Mystetstv Str.,  Kharkiv,  Ukraine \n \n\n<br>e-mail: alexey.v.sergeyev@gmail.com<br>\n<sup>3</sup> \n \n INAF &#8211; Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte, Salita Moiariello, 16,  80131   Napoli,  Italy \n \n\n<br>e-mail: chiara.spiniello@gmail.com<br>\n<sup>4</sup> \n \n European Southern Observatory, Karl-Schwarschild-Str. 2,  85748   Garching,  Germany \n \n<br>\n<sup>5</sup> \n \n INAF &#8211; Osservatorio Astrofisico di Arcetri,  Largo Enrico Fermi 5,  50125   Firenze,  Italy \n \n<br>\n<sup>6</sup> \n \nSchool of Physics and Astronomy, Sun Yat-sen University, 2 Daxue Road, Tangjia,  Zhuhai,  Guangdong   519082,  PR China \n \n<br>\n<sup>7</sup> \n \nDARK, Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen University,  Lyngbyvej 2,  2100   Copenhagen,  Denmark \n \n<br>\n<sup>8</sup> \n \nKapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen,  PO Box 800,  9700 AV   Groningen,  The Netherlands \n \n<br>\n<sup>9</sup> \n \nLeiden Observatory, Leiden University,  PO Box 9513,  2300 RA   Leiden,  The Netherlands \n \n<br>\n<sup>10</sup> \n \n INAF &#8211; Osservatorio Astronomico di Padova,  Via dell&#8217;Osservatorio 5,  35122   Padova,  Italy \n \n<br>\n<sup>11</sup> \n \n Shanghai Astronomical Observatory (SHAO),  Nandan Road 80,  Shanghai   200030,  PR China \n \n<br>\n<sup>12</sup> \n \n College of Physics of Jilin University,  Qianjin Street 2699,  Changchun   130012,  PR China \n \n<br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>\n3 \nJune \n2019\n<br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>\n8 \nOctober \n2019\n</p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n<p><i>Context.</i> The KiDS Strongly lensed QUAsar Detection project (KiDS-SQuaD) is aimed at finding as many previously undiscovered gravitational lensed quasars as possible in the Kilo Degree Survey. This is the second paper of this series where we present a new, automatic object-classification method based on the machine learning technique.</p>\n<p><i>Aims.</i> The main goal of this paper is to build a catalogue of bright extragalactic objects (galaxies and quasars) from the KiDS Data Release 4, with minimum stellar contamination and preserving the completeness as much as possible. We show here that this catalogue represents the perfect starting point to search for reliable gravitationally lensed quasar candidates.</p>\n<p><i>Methods.</i> After testing some of the most used machine learning algorithms, decision-tree-based classifiers, we decided to use CatBoost, which was specifically trained with the aim of creating a sample of extragalactic sources that is as clean of stars as possible. We discuss the input data, define the training sample for the classifier, give quantitative estimates of its performances, and finally describe the validation results with <i>Gaia</i> DR2, AllWISE, and GAMA catalogues.</p>\n<p><i>Results.</i> We built and made available to the scientific community the KiDS Bright EXtraGalactic Objects catalogue (KiDS-BEXGO), specifically created to find gravitational lenses but applicable to a wide number of scientific purposes. The KiDS-BEXGO catalogue is made of &#8776;6 million sources classified as quasars (&#8776;200&#8198;000) and galaxies (&#8776;5.7 M) up to <i>r</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;22<sup>m</sup>. To demonstrate the potential of the catalogue in the search for strongly lensed quasars, we selected &#8776;950 &#8220;Multiplets&#8221;: close pairs of quasars or galaxies surrounded by at least one quasar. We present cutouts and coordinates of the 12 most reliable gravitationally lensed quasar candidates. We showed that employing a machine learning method decreases the stellar contaminants within the gravitationally lensed candidates, comparing the current results to the previous ones, presented in the first paper from this series.</p>\n<p><i>Conclusions.</i> Our work presents the first comprehensive identification of bright extragalactic objects in KiDS DR4 data, which is, for us, the first necessary step towards finding strong gravitational lenses in wide-sky photometric surveys, but has also many other more general astrophysical applications.</p>\n<div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>gravitational lensing: strong / methods: data analysis / surveys / catalogs / quasars: general / galaxies: general</p></div>\n<div class=\"note\">\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN1\"></a><sup>&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">The KiDS Bright EXtraGalactic Objects (KiDS-BEXGO) catalogue is also available at the CDS via anonymous ftp to <a href=\"http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/\" target=\"_blank\">cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr</a> (<a href=\"ftp://130.79.128.5\" target=\"_blank\">130.79.128.5</a>) or via <a href=\"http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/cat/J/A+A/632/A56\" target=\"_blank\">http://cdsarc.u-strasbg.fr/viz-bin/cat/J/A+A/632/A56</a></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; ESO 2019</i></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>Modern deep and wide-field sky photometric surveys offer an unprecedented opportunity to collect large amounts of data for statistical studies of the nearby and far-away universe. Over the last decade, they have provided new insights into the structure of our own Galaxy as well as of the extragalactic objects at all scales, from giant galaxies to faint and compact stellar systems. Deep surveys allow us to trace the mass assembly of galaxy clusters and to map the intracluster light components (globular clusters, dwarf galaxies, and diffuse light). They have also opened the time domain leading to a new understanding of the transient phenomena in the universe.</p>\n<p>One of the fields where large sky surveys can be of precious help is strong gravitational lensing and in particular in finding new lensed quasars. Strong gravitationally lensed quasars are very rare objects: one quasar in &#8764;10<sup>3.5</sup> is expected to be strongly lensed for <i>i</i>-band-limiting magnitude deeper than <i>i</i>&#8196;&#8776;&#8196;21<sup>m</sup> (see e.g. Fig. 3 and Sect. 3.1 in <a name=\"InR86\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R86\">Oguri &amp; Marshall 2010</a>). However, it was clear upon their first discovery (<a name=\"InR125\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R125\">Walsh et al. 1979</a>) that these systems are extremely useful tools for observational cosmology and extragalactic astrophysics (see e.g. the review by <a name=\"InR65\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R65\">Kochanek 2006</a>).</p>\n<p>When a quasar is strongly lensed by a galaxy, it results in multiple images of the same source, accompanied by arcs or rings that map the lensed host of the quasar. The light curves of different images are offset by measurable time delays that depend on the cosmological distances to lens and source and on the gravitational potential of the lens (<a name=\"InR98\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R98\">Refsdal 1964</a>). This in turn enables one-step measurements of the expansion history of the Universe (primarily <i>H</i><sub>0</sub>, <a name=\"InR117\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R117\">Suyu et al. 2014</a>) and the dark matter halos of massive lens galaxies (<a name=\"InR58\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R58\">Keeton &amp; Moustakas 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR130\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R130\">Zackrisson &amp; Riehm 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR46\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R46\">Gilman et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR75\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R75\">Liao et al. 2018</a>).</p>\n<p>In addition to the deflection caused by the lens, the light of the quasar can also be deflected by the gravitational field of other low-mass bodies moving along the line-of-sight (10<sup>&#8722;6</sup>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>m</i>/<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;10<sup>3</sup>, e.g. single stars, brown dwarfs, planets, globular clusters, etc.). This <i>microlensing</i> phenomenon provides a quantitative handle on the stellar content of the lens galaxies (<a name=\"InR105\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R105\">Schechter &amp; Wambsganss 2002</a>; <a name=\"InR17\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R17\">Bate et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR88\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R88\">Oguri et al. 2014</a>), and can simultaneously provide constraints on the inner structure of the source quasar, namely accretion disk size, thermal profile, and the geometry of the broad-line region (<a name=\"InR9\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R9\">Anguita et al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR110\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R110\">Sluse et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR83\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R83\">Motta et al. 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR47\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R47\">Guerras et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R19\">Braibant et al. 2014</a>). Finally, compared with galaxy&#8211;galaxy lenses, lensed quasars are detectable down to smaller image-separations, thereby ensuring more complete coverage of the lens mass range.</p>\n<p>Unfortunately, progress in these fields has been limited by the paucity of confirmed systems. This is why in the last decade enormous effort has been devoted, in conjunction with the advent of deep wide-field sky photometric surveys, to the search for new lenses. These surveys offer an unprecedented opportunity to search for strong gravitational lenses on a much larger portion of the sky (<a name=\"InR87\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R87\">Oguri et al. 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR119\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R119\">Treu et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR77\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R77\">Lemon et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR102\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R102\">Rusu et al. 2019</a>; <a name=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R6\">Agnello et al. 2018a</a>,<a name=\"InR7\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R7\">b</a>; <a name=\"InR3\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R3\">Agnello &amp; Spiniello 2019</a>). However, it is necessary to develop and use sophisticated automated methods (e.g. Decision Trees, <a name=\"InR97\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R97\">Quinlan 1986</a>, Na&#239;ve Bayes, <a name=\"InR37\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R37\">Duda &amp; Hart 1973</a>, Neural Networks, <a name=\"InR99\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R99\">Rumelhart et al. 1986</a>, Support Vector Machines, <a name=\"InR123\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R123\">Vapnik 1995</a>; <a name=\"InR28\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R28\">Cortes &amp; Vapnik 1995</a>) to process the very large amount of data that the surveys provide.</p>\n<p>Obviously, the first step to find gravitationally lensed quasars is to classify objects, selecting extragalactic objects among millions of sources, while minimizing stellar contamination as much as possible. More generally speaking, the identification of extragalactic objects, quasars, and galaxies at all redshifts is an all-important task that can help to answer to a wide range of astrophysical and cosmological questions, such as the relationship between active galactic nuclei (AGNs) and host galaxies or the cosmic evolution of super massive black holes or the formation and evolution of galaxies (<a name=\"InR36\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R36\">Driver et al. 2009</a>) across cosmic time (<a name=\"InR57\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R57\">Kauffmann &amp; Haehnelt 2000</a>; <a name=\"InR50\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R50\">Haehnelt &amp; Kauffmann 2000</a>; <a name=\"InR129\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R129\">Wyithe &amp; Loeb 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR52\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R52\">Hopkins et al. 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR103\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R103\">Shankar et al. 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR104\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R104\">Shen et al. 2009</a>).</p>\n<p>Machine learning (ML) methods have proven to be very effective in identifying and classifying extragalactic sources (e.g. <a name=\"InR41\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R41\">Eyer &amp; Blake 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR39\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R39\">Elting et al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR61\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R61\">Kim et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR45\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R45\">Gieseke et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR62\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R62\">Kov&#225;cs &amp; Szapudi 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R21\">Brescia et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR91\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R91\">Peters et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR63\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R63\">Krakowski et al. 2016</a>, <a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R64\">2018</a>; <a name=\"InR124\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R124\">Viquar et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR59\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R59\">Khramtsov &amp; Akhmetov 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR85\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R85\">Nolte et al. 2019</a>; <a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R13\">Bai et al. 2019</a>) with respect to any manual colour cut. A specific type of classifiers, the ensembles of decision trees, were shown to be advantageous in the identification of extragalactic sources, and in particular quasars (<a name=\"InR15\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R15\">Ball et al. 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR23\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R23\">Carrasco et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR51\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R51\">Hernitschek et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR107\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R107\">Schindler et al. 2017</a>, <a name=\"InR108\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R108\">2018</a>; <a name=\"InR109\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R109\">Sergeyev et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR56\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R56\">Jin et al. 2019</a>; <a name=\"InR84\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R84\">Nakoneczny et al. 2019</a>). They allow the user to explore, with a little human intervention and affordable computing time, large datasets, thus selecting candidates with less stringent pre-selection criteria, maximizing the precision (recovery rate), and minimizing the stellar contamination.</p>\n<p>More specifically, ML methods to search for strong gravitational lenses have also been developed, although we note that the large majority of them are built to find galaxy&#8211;galaxy lenses, rather than lensed quasars, using a deep learning approach (e.g. <a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R22\">Cabanac et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR90\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R90\">Paraficz et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR73\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R73\">Lanusse et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR82\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R82\">Metcalf et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR92\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R92\">Petrillo et al. 2017</a>, <a name=\"InR93\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R93\">2019a</a>,<a name=\"InR94\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R94\">b</a>; but see also <a name=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R4\">Agnello et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR68\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R68\">Krone-Martins et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR54\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R54\">Jacobs et al. 2019</a> for lensed quasars).</p>\n<p>It is very important to note that at the catalogue-level lensed quasars can be either point-like sources (and hence must be reliably separated from stars), or single extended objects. Indeed, when the deflector gives a non-negligible contribution to the light of the whole system or the multiple images are blended together, the lensing system produces an &#8220;extended&#8221;, single match in a photometric catalogue, rather than many &#8220;point-like&#8221; matches. Therefore, the first step towards finding strong gravitationally lensed quasars is to select both galaxies and quasars, possibly discarding all the galactic objects. This is indeed the main focus of this paper, which is the second of the KiDS Strongly lensed QUAsar Detection (KiDS-SQuad) project, and presents an ML classifier specifically designed to remove stellar contaminants from a catalogue of bright extragalactic sources in the Kilo Degree Survey (KiDS, <a name=\"InR31\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R31\">de Jong et al. 2013</a>).</p>\n<p>This paper is organized as follows. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S1\">1</a> we introduce the search for gravitationally lensed quasars in KiDS. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S2\">2</a> we give a general overview of the catalogues and data we use. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S5\">3</a> we discuss the method to classify objects and isolate extragalactic ones using optical and infrared deep photometry, and we introduce and describe our own classification pipeline. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S10\">4</a> we present the main result of this pipeline: the catalogue of Bright EXtraGalactic Objects from KiDS DR4 &#8211; KiDS-BEXGO, as well as different validation tests based on external data to assess the performance of the classifier. Finally, in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S14\">5</a> we focus on &#8220;Multiplets&#8221;: close pairs of quasars, or galaxies surrounded by at least one quasar (within 5&#8243;), which represent the best strong gravitationally lensed quasar candidates. We present our conclusions and future perspectives in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S18\">6</a>. In addition, we present in the appendix a direct comparison of three different machine learning methods that we tested, all based on decision trees.</p>\n<p><i>The KiDS Strongly lensed QUAsar Detection project.</i> The KiDS survey (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R31\">de Jong et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR71\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R71\">Kuijken et al. 2019</a>) is ideal to identify and classify objects and to search for strong gravitational lenses thanks to its high spatial resolution (0.2&#8243; pixel<sup>&#8722;1</sup>, <a name=\"InR24\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R24\">Capaccioli &amp; Schipani 2011</a>), excellent (for ground observation standards) seeing quality (mean <i>r</i>-band <i>F</i><i>W</i><i>H</i><i>M</i> &#8776; 0.70), depth (25<sup>m</sup> in <i>r</i>-band), and wide footprint (1350 deg<sup>2</sup> have been covered and the data will be released with DR5). Taking advantage of these characteristics of the survey, we recently started the KiDS-SQuaD project presented in <a name=\"InR113\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R113\">Spiniello et al. (2018</a>, hereafter Paper I).</p>\n<p>With KiDS-SQuaD, we are carrying out a systematic census of lensed quasars with the final goal being to build a statistically relevant sample of lenses, covering a wide range of parameters (geometrical configurations, deflector masses and morphologies, redshifts, and nature of the sources). This would enable us to study the dark matter halos of lens galaxies up to <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;1 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R105\">Schechter &amp; Wambsganss 2002</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R17\">Bate et al. 2011</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R117\">Suyu et al. 2014</a>) as well as the quasar-host galaxy co-evolution up to <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;2 (<a name=\"InR101\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R101\">Rusu et al. 2014</a>; <a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R5\">Agnello et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R33\">Ding et al. 2017</a>), to put constraints on the inner structure of the quasar accretion disk (size and thermal profile; e.g. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R9\">Anguita et al. 2008</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R83\">Motta et al. 2012</a>) and on the broad-line-region geometry (e.g. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R110\">Sluse et al. 2011</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R47\">Guerras et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R19\">Braibant et al. 2014</a>), and finally to gather precise cosmography (e.g. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R117\">Suyu et al. 2014</a>, <a name=\"InR118\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R118\">2017</a>).</p>\n<p>The power of KiDS in the object-classification challenge has already been demonstrated in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R84\">Nakoneczny et al. (2019</a>, hereafter N19) who built and released a catalogue of quasars from KiDS DR3 (440 deg<sup>2</sup>), classified with a random forest supervised ML model, trained on Sloan Digital Sky Survey DR14 (SDSS DR14, <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R1\">Abolfathi et al. 2018</a>) spectroscopic data. The approach we undertake in this paper is similar to the one presented in N19, as we also use KiDS data as input and SDSS as a training sample, although we fine-tune and customize our pipelines to be more suitable for the search of lensed quasars. Moreover, the biggest difference between these works is that now we have available photometry in nine bands. In fact, the optical data in KIDS are now (starting from DR4, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R71\">Kuijken et al. 2019</a>) complemented by infrared data from the VISTA Kilo-degree INfrared Galaxy (VIKING) survey, covering the same KiDS area in the <i>Z</i>, <i>Y</i>, <i>J</i>, <i>H</i>, and <i>K</i><sub><i>s</i></sub> near-infrared bands (<a name=\"InR38\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R38\">Edge et al. 2013</a>). Thus, the KiDS &#215; VIKING photometric dataset provides a unique deep, wide coverage in nine bands (<i>u</i>,&#8198;<i>g</i>,&#8198;<i>r</i>,&#8198;<i>i</i>,&#8198;<i>Z</i>,&#8198;<i>Y</i>,&#8198;<i>J</i>,&#8198;<i>H</i>,&#8198;<i>K</i><sub><i>s</i></sub>), which has proven to be extremely effective in separating quasars from stars using photometric characteristics (e.g. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R23\">Carrasco et al. 2015</a>). Indeed, one of the limitations of the first paper of this series was the manual optical colour selection we used to select quasar-like objects. In the approach taken in this first publication, the number of final lensed quasar candidates highly depends on the selection criteria that are somehow arbitrary and often calibrated on previous findings. Moreover, generally, this number is of the order of 10&#8197;&#247;&#8197;30 sources per deg<sup>2</sup>, making the necessary second step of visual inspection very difficult and long. To avoid manual arbitrary cuts and to deal with the larger amount of data coming from the fourth and fifth KiDS Data Release (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R71\">Kuijken et al. 2019</a>), and above all from new deep, wide-field surveys such as Euclid (<a name=\"InR74\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R74\">Laureijs et al. 2011</a>) or LSST (<a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R53\">Ivezi&#263; &amp; LSST Science Collaboration 2013</a>), we developed a method based on ML, which we present here. This automatic method allows us to more efficiently pinpoint extragalactic systems while eliminating as much stellar contamination as possible.</p>\n<p>Although, as already stated, many ML classifiers have been developed and released, we decided to build our own pipeline in order to be able to fully customize the characteristics and parameters of the algorithm. As we explain in detail in this paper, we require high completeness and purity, in an attempt to build a catalogue of extragalactic objects that is as clean from stars as possible, and at the same time as complete as possible. Therefore, developing our own tool and releasing the resulting catalogue is the best possible choice.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. Data overview</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>2.1. The input catalogue from KiDS DR4</h3>\n<p>The KiDS survey (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R31\">de Jong et al. 2013</a>) is one of the European Southern Observatory (ESO) public surveys carried on with the VLT Survey Telescope (VST, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R24\">Capaccioli &amp; Schipani 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R25\">Capaccioli et al. 2012</a>). Starting from DR4 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R71\">Kuijken et al. 2019</a>), KiDS optical photometric data, covering 1350 deg<sup>2</sup> in <i>u</i>,&#8198;<i>g</i>,&#8198;<i>r</i>,&#8198;<i>i</i> bands, are complemented with infrared data from the VISTA Kilo-Degree Infrared Galaxy Survey (VIKING, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R38\">Edge et al. 2013</a>), covering the same region on sky in five near-infrared bands (<i>Z</i>,&#8198;<i>Y</i>,&#8198;<i>J</i>,&#8198;<i>H</i>,&#8198;<i>K</i><sub><i>s</i></sub>). Typical magnitude limits for each of the nine bands are 24.2, 25.1, 25.0, 23.6, 22.7, 22.0, 21.8, 21.1, 21.2 (AB magnitudes, 5<i>&#963;</i> in 2&#8243; aperture), with seeing generally below 1.0&#8243; (<a name=\"InR128\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R128\">Wright et al. 2019</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R71\">Kuijken et al. 2019</a>). Throughout this paper we make use of extinction-corrected Gaussian Aperture and PSF (GAaP, <a name=\"InR69\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R69\">Kuijken 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R70\">Kuijken et al. 2015</a>) magnitudes.</p>\n<p>We started from the <i>r</i>-band catalogue, which is the one with the best seeing (0.7&#8243;, on average), and we selected 9 596 412 sources with <i>r</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;22<sup>m</sup> and good aperture-matched photometry measured in each of the other eight bands (we removed all the sources with <tt>MAGERR_GAAP</tt> &gt; 1<sup>m</sup> in each of the band). Limiting the classification to only bright objects is necessary to avoid any extrapolation to uncovered regions in the space of features. We therefore only consider the magnitude range covered by spectroscopically confirmed objects from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 14 (SDSS DR14, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R1\">Abolfathi et al. 2018</a>) that we use as a training sample. The histogram of the <i>r</i>-band magnitude distribution for the whole KIDS DR4 and for the spectroscopically confirmed objects that we use as a training sample is shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F1\">1</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1.</span></a><p>Histogram of the <i>r</i> magnitude distribution for the full KiDS DR4 catalogue (blue) and the SDSS &#215; KiDS training sample (red).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>The same approach (using the same magnitude threshold) has already been tested and was successfully used for KiDS-DR3 in N19. Finally, as we describe in more detail below, we also use the magnitude-dependent parameter <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> for the source classification. This has already proven to be a very important feature in N19.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>2.2. The training sample from SDSS DR14</h3>\n<p>To provide accurate classification, one needs to use a large sample of objects with known true classes. Such data can be obtained from spectroscopic surveys. For our purpose, following the approach of N19, we used the SDSS DR14<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN5\">1</a></sup> catalogue.</p>\n<p>The SDSS DR14 catalogue contains 4 311 571 spectroscopically confirmed objects, classified based on their spectra in three main classes: galaxies (2 546 963 objects), quasars (824 548 objects), and stars (940 060 objects). We preserve this structure in our classification, setting up a three-label classification system, which we describe in detail in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S5\">3</a>.</p>\n<p>We assume that a quasar (hereafter, <tt>QSO</tt>) is a point-like source<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN6\">2</a></sup> with <tt>QSO</tt> class and <tt>QSO</tt> or <tt>BROADLINE</tt> subclass; a normal galaxy (hereafter, <tt>GALAXY</tt>) is an extended source that has a <tt>GALAXY</tt> class label without <tt>STARFORMING, BROADLINE,</tt> or <tt>STARBURST BROADLINE</tt> subclasses. The star labelling in SDSS does not have subclasses; therefore we simply assume that the source is a star (hereafter, <tt>STAR</tt>) if it is classified as such in the catalogue.</p>\n<p>We cross-matched the SDSS DR14 full catalogue with the catalogue of bright sources from KiDS DR4 described above (<i>r</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;22<sup>m</sup>) using a 1.0 arcsec radius and obtaining in this way a training sample of 183 048 sources; some of these sources however have dubious spectroscopic classification.</p>\n<p>Careful cleaning is very important for our scientific purpose, but an automatic masking procedure, eliminating all the dubious cases and often applied in classification pipelines to reach the highest possible pureness, is not appropriate here. In fact, this kind of masking might cause the loss of interesting objects with complex morphology and photometric properties, which can indeed be very good lens candidates<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN7\">3</a></sup>. We therefore paid particular attention to the cleaning procedure, carrying it out manually and interactively.</p>\n<p>In particular, we used this first &#8220;unpolished&#8221; training sample to train the classifiers (which we describe in the following section). We then visually inspected all the misclassified objects (of the order of a few hundred)<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN8\">4</a></sup>. Interestingly, during inspection, we discovered that SDSS DR14 indeed contains a few objects with incorrect labels.</p>\n<p>Among these, we identified a few white dwarf and compact galaxies labelled as <tt>QSO</tt>, blended sources where one of the components is a star or stars projected into a galaxy. Since classifiers trained on such a dataset can inherit these mistakes, we removed the sources for which the true class did not fit with its imaging and/or spectral properties. The whole classification pipeline was iterated a few times, testing the cleaning also with different classifiers (see following section). We note that the total number of removed sources does not exceed a few percent of the training sample, but that the classification results before and after this iterative cleaning procedure are not identical, with the classifier learned with the &#8220;clean&#8221; training sample producing better results in terms of pureness.</p>\n<p>Finally, we test the impact of changing the threshold we choose on the photometric errors of each single band to get a better handle on the importance of our assumptions in building the input catalogue and the best training sample for it. In particular, we tested three different upper limits for the errors on the magnitudes of the training sample: 1<sup>m</sup>, 0.5<sup>m</sup> and 0.3<sup>m</sup>. Also, in this case, we trained the classifiers three times with three different training sets made of objects passing these three thresholds and then we compared the performances. We found negligible differences in purity and completeness (at the 0.1% level) in the classification of the training sample. Finally, we also compared the predictions for the whole input catalogue obtained using the three different training samples, finding again no significant differences in the distribution of the sources among the classes. We therefore decided to use the training sample with the largest number of objects and the same error threshold as the input catalogue (1<sup>m</sup>).</p>\n<p>In conclusion, after removing the sources (i) with bad spectroscopic redshift estimation (for which zWarning&#8196;&gt; &#8196;0), (ii) missing one or more of the nine optical&#8211;infrared magnitudes, (iii) with high photometric errors (&gt; 1<sup>m</sup> in each filter) and (iv) that are accidental duplicates retrieved after our cross-matching procedure, we ended up with 121 375 sources, of which 24 307 sources classified as <tt>STAR</tt>, 12 152 sources classified as <tt>QSO</tt>, and 84 917 sources labelled as <tt>GALAXY</tt>. This catalogue, hereafter named SDSS &#215; KiDS, is used in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S8\">3.3</a> as a training sample for the classifiers.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>3. Classification</h2>\n<p>Since stars, quasars, and galaxies have different photometric characteristics, it is in principle possible to separate them on the basis of their (optical and infrared) colours.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>3.1. Feature selection</h3>\n<p>Our first task was to define a feature space for the objects using the nine magnitudes (<i>u</i>,&#8198;<i>g</i>,&#8198;<i>r</i>,&#8198;<i>i</i>,&#8198;<i>Z</i>,&#8198;<i>Y</i>,&#8198;<i>J</i>,&#8198;<i>H</i>,&#8198;<i>K</i><sub><i>s</i></sub>) provided by KiDS and VIKING. Even though there are only eight independent colours, some colour combinations may be more distinctive, and so we chose to examine all 36 pairwise magnitude combinations. We also added the KiDS <i>r</i>-band <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> parameter to the feature set. This corresponds to the &#8220;stellarity&#8221; of a source, which is a continuous measure of whether the object is extended (<tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> = 0) or point-like (<tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> = 1) and has proven to be a very powerful feature in the classification (e.g. N19). As shown in Fig. 8 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R31\">de Jong et al. (2013)</a>, the <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> parameter depends on the signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) and is an effective way to separate stars from galaxies only for data with <i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;50 in <i>r</i>-band. Therefore, an alternative way to select the input data to classify, which would probably also allow investigation of fainter magnitudes, might be to put a cut in the S/N rather than on the <i>r</i>-band magnitude. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R84\">Nakoneczny et al. (2019)</a> showed that, although magnitudes contribute less to classification than colours and stellarity index, the output based on colours only was different from that using also magnitudes. In this respect, we note that the five infrared bands from VIKING strengthen the separation of stars from quasars and galaxies and thus allow us to follow a physically motivated and model-driven approach that consider only colours in the classification.</p>\n<p>Colours and stellarity values of the sources correspond to the coordinates in the thirty-seven-dimensional feature space, in which the classification has been performed.</p>\n<p>Our chosen three-class labelling (stars, quasars, galaxies) yields the purest identification of quasars, compared to the two-class scheme (stars and quasars together as point-like, and galaxies as extended sources) or the four-class scheme (stars, quasars, regular galaxies, and galaxies with strong emission lines). Also, we stress that a two-class problem, which only separates stars from extragalactic sources, is not adequate for our scientific purposes. It is true that to find gravitationally lensed quasars, we need a catalogue that contains both galaxies and quasars, but we need a combined morphological and photometric selection in order to identify different combinations of objects (quasar pairs, quasar+star alignments, lenses) that are blended into extended objects by the survey pipelines (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S14\">5</a>).</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>3.2. Choice of tree-based method</h3>\n<p>In the following sections, we describe the classification algorithm and calibration strategy that we use to build our catalogue, which was the end product of a large series of tests and experiments we carried out, also using different classification schemes, as detailed in the Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#APP1\">A</a>. We tested three different classifiers, all based on decision trees (Random Forests and two different Gradient Boosting approaches). In the end, we chose the CatBoost (<a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R35\">Dorogush et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR96\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R96\">Prokhorenkova et al. 2018</a>) scheme, out of the two Gradient Boosting (GB, <a name=\"InR42\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R42\">Friedman 2000</a>) ensemble algorithms that we tested, because it provided the best performance during the training process, which is described below.</p>\n<p>In general, GB is an ensemble algorithm that constructs a learner by fitting in an iterative way the gradients of the prediction residuals from the previously constructed <i>weak</i> learners, typically decision trees (gradient boosting decision trees (GBDTs)). In particular, CatBoost is a novel, fast, scalable, high-performance open-source GBDT library<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN9\">5</a></sup>. Compared to other GBDT algorithms, CatBoost has the advantage of using Ordered Boosting (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R96\">Prokhorenkova et al. 2018</a>) to curb the overfitting problem, as we highlight in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#APP1\">A</a>. To our knowledge, this is the first application of the CatBoost algorithm to an astronomical task.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>3.3. Fine-tuning and learning process</h3>\n<p>In order to quantify the performance of a classifier, one needs to define a set of validation data and the type of learning with respect to the training-to-validation division. We therefore split the validation into two groups: out-of-fold (OOF) and hold-out. The hold-out sample consists of a random subsample of the initial training data which will be used only for the final performance quantification. The remaining part of the initial sample is used to train the classifiers with a <i>k</i>-fold cross-validation procedure. This is a common method to train classifiers and directly compare classification algorithms. Briefly, one divides the training sample into <i>k</i> randomly partitioned disjoint equal parts. The classification algorithm then trains on <i>k</i>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;1 parts and the remaining one is used as validating data. This process is repeated <i>k</i> times, each time using one of the <i>k</i> disjoint subsamples as validating data and obtaining a prediction from it. The combination of these <i>k</i> predictions forms the so-called OOF sample. Similarly, to obtain the prediction on the new data, the <i>k</i> predictions from each of the fold models are averaged together. A schematic view of the learning process is visualized in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F2\">2</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2.</span></a><p>Schematic view of the learning via ten-fold cross validation procedure and validation with the OOF and the hold-out samples drawn from the initial training sample.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>Starting from the SDSS &#215; KiDS sample of 121 376 sources, we randomly selected 20% of it as hold-out sample and use the remaining 80% as OOF training sample in the cross-validation process<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN10\">6</a></sup>. We stress that among the classifiers that we tested, CatBoost returned the best performance both on the hold-out and OOF samples.</p>\n<p>Before training can take place, the classifier has a list of <i>hyper</i>-parameters that have to be tuned to reach the highest possible classification quality. This is true for each of the different classifiers that we tested. For this purpose, we performed an optimal hyperparameter search on 60% of the initial training sample via three-fold cross-validation with a &#8220;BayesSearch&#8221; for CatBoost<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN11\">7</a></sup>.</p>\n<p>While tuning the wide range of hyperparameters for CatBoost, we noticed that the most influential ones were the <tt>max_depth</tt> and the <tt>early_stopping</tt> parameters. We selected max_depth&#8198;&#8196;=&#8196;&#8198;8 and early_stopping&#8198;&#8196;=&#8196;&#8198;150 after BayesSearch, with a maximum number of trees of 3500.</p>\n<p>Moreover, we applied a weighting criterion to the loss function for the CatBoost model to further decrease the contaminants by stars in the extragalactic objects catalogue (see Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S19\">A.1</a> for more details).</p>\n<p>After this hyperparameter fine-tuning, we finally trained CatBoost with the same training and validation data and with a ten-fold cross-validation (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F2\">2</a>). The result of the performance for the final CatBoost model (after the fine-tuning) is presented as confusion matrices in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F3\">3</a> for both the OOF sample (top) and the hold-out sample (bottom). Using the weighting for stars and galaxies, we saw a significant improvement in the purity of the quasar sample; in fact, by comparing the confusion matrices before and after re-weighting the loss function (see appendix), one can see that the rate of stars misclassified as quasars decreased from &#8776;0.60% to &#8776;0.30%. CatBoost lost only &lt; 1.50% of the quasars, thus only marginally decreasing the resulting completeness of this class.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3.</span></a><p>Confusion matrices for the final version of CatBoost, after weighting the loss function, performed on the OOF sample (<i>top panel</i>) and the hold-out sample (<i>bottom panel</i>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>3.4. Feature importance</h3>\n<p>Another notable result that we can get with CatBoost is the relative importance of each feature in the classification procedure. Feature importance, calculated with a decision tree, shows the frequency with which a certain feature occurs in the tree. In such a way, the higher frequency is directly related to the higher feature contribution to separate the sources, that is the importance of a given feature.
