For our purpose, following the approach of N19, we used the SDSS DR14<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN5\">1</a></sup> catalogue.</p>\n<p>The SDSS DR14 catalogue contains 4 311 571 spectroscopically confirmed objects, classified based on their spectra in three main classes: galaxies (2 546 963 objects), quasars (824 548 objects), and stars (940 060 objects). We preserve this structure in our classification, setting up a three-label classification system, which we describe in detail in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S5\">3</a>.</p>\n<p>We assume that a quasar (hereafter, <tt>QSO</tt>) is a point-like source<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN6\">2</a></sup> with <tt>QSO</tt> class and <tt>QSO</tt> or <tt>BROADLINE</tt> subclass; a normal galaxy (hereafter, <tt>GALAXY</tt>) is an extended source that has a <tt>GALAXY</tt> class label without <tt>STARFORMING, BROADLINE,</tt> or <tt>STARBURST BROADLINE</tt> subclasses. The star labelling in SDSS does not have subclasses; therefore we simply assume that the source is a star (hereafter, <tt>STAR</tt>) if it is classified as such in the catalogue.</p>\n<p>We cross-matched the SDSS DR14 full catalogue with the catalogue of bright sources from KiDS DR4 described above (<i>r</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;22<sup>m</sup>) using a 1.0 arcsec radius and obtaining in this way a training sample of 183 048 sources; some of these sources however have dubious spectroscopic classification.</p>\n<p>Careful cleaning is very important for our scientific purpose, but an automatic masking procedure, eliminating all the dubious cases and often applied in classification pipelines to reach the highest possible pureness, is not appropriate here. In fact, this kind of masking might cause the loss of interesting objects with complex morphology and photometric properties, which can indeed be very good lens candidates<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN7\">3</a></sup>. We therefore paid particular attention to the cleaning procedure, carrying it out manually and interactively.</p>\n<p>In particular, we used this first &#8220;unpolished&#8221; training sample to train the classifiers (which we describe in the following section). We then visually inspected all the misclassified objects (of the order of a few hundred)<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN8\">4</a></sup>. Interestingly, during inspection, we discovered that SDSS DR14 indeed contains a few objects with incorrect labels.</p>\n<p>Among these, we identified a few white dwarf and compact galaxies labelled as <tt>QSO</tt>, blended sources where one of the components is a star or stars projected into a galaxy. Since classifiers trained on such a dataset can inherit these mistakes, we removed the sources for which the true class did not fit with its imaging and/or spectral properties. The whole classification pipeline was iterated a few times, testing the cleaning also with different classifiers (see following section). We note that the total number of removed sources does not exceed a few percent of the training sample, but that the classification results before and after this iterative cleaning procedure are not identical, with the classifier learned with the &#8220;clean&#8221; training sample producing better results in terms of pureness.</p>\n<p>Finally, we test the impact of changing the threshold we choose on the photometric errors of each single band to get a better handle on the importance of our assumptions in building the input catalogue and the best training sample for it. In particular, we tested three different upper limits for the errors on the magnitudes of the training sample: 1<sup>m</sup>, 0.5<sup>m</sup> and 0.3<sup>m</sup>. Also, in this case, we trained the classifiers three times with three different training sets made of objects passing these three thresholds and then we compared the performances. We found negligible differences in purity and completeness (at the 0.1% level) in the classification of the training sample. Finally, we also compared the predictions for the whole input catalogue obtained using the three different training samples, finding again no significant differences in the distribution of the sources among the classes. We therefore decided to use the training sample with the largest number of objects and the same error threshold as the input catalogue (1<sup>m</sup>).</p>\n<p>In conclusion, after removing the sources (i) with bad spectroscopic redshift estimation (for which zWarning&#8196;&gt; &#8196;0), (ii) missing one or more of the nine optical&#8211;infrared magnitudes, (iii) with high photometric errors (&gt; 1<sup>m</sup> in each filter) and (iv) that are accidental duplicates retrieved after our cross-matching procedure, we ended up with 121 375 sources, of which 24 307 sources classified as <tt>STAR</tt>, 12 152 sources classified as <tt>QSO</tt>, and 84 917 sources labelled as <tt>GALAXY</tt>. This catalogue, hereafter named SDSS &#215; KiDS, is used in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S8\">3.3</a> as a training sample for the classifiers.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>3. Classification</h2>\n<p>Since stars, quasars, and galaxies have different photometric characteristics, it is in principle possible to separate them on the basis of their (optical and infrared) colours.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>3.1. Feature selection</h3>\n<p>Our first task was to define a feature space for the objects using the nine magnitudes (<i>u</i>,&#8198;<i>g</i>,&#8198;<i>r</i>,&#8198;<i>i</i>,&#8198;<i>Z</i>,&#8198;<i>Y</i>,&#8198;<i>J</i>,&#8198;<i>H</i>,&#8198;<i>K</i><sub><i>s</i></sub>) provided by KiDS and VIKING. Even though there are only eight independent colours, some colour combinations may be more distinctive, and so we chose to examine all 36 pairwise magnitude combinations. We also added the KiDS <i>r</i>-band <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> parameter to the feature set. This corresponds to the &#8220;stellarity&#8221; of a source, which is a continuous measure of whether the object is extended (<tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> = 0) or point-like (<tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> = 1) and has proven to be a very powerful feature in the classification (e.g. N19). As shown in Fig. 8 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R31\">de Jong et al. (2013)</a>, the <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> parameter depends on the signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) and is an effective way to separate stars from galaxies only for data with <i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;50 in <i>r</i>-band. Therefore, an alternative way to select the input data to classify, which would probably also allow investigation of fainter magnitudes, might be to put a cut in the S/N rather than on the <i>r</i>-band magnitude. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R84\">Nakoneczny et al. (2019)</a> showed that, although magnitudes contribute less to classification than colours and stellarity index, the output based on colours only was different from that using also magnitudes. In this respect, we note that the five infrared bands from VIKING strengthen the separation of stars from quasars and galaxies and thus allow us to follow a physically motivated and model-driven approach that consider only colours in the classification.</p>\n<p>Colours and stellarity values of the sources correspond to the coordinates in the thirty-seven-dimensional feature space, in which the classification has been performed.</p>\n<p>Our chosen three-class labelling (stars, quasars, galaxies) yields the purest identification of quasars, compared to the two-class scheme (stars and quasars together as point-like, and galaxies as extended sources) or the four-class scheme (stars, quasars, regular galaxies, and galaxies with strong emission lines). Also, we stress that a two-class problem, which only separates stars from extragalactic sources, is not adequate for our scientific purposes. It is true that to find gravitationally lensed quasars, we need a catalogue that contains both galaxies and quasars, but we need a combined morphological and photometric selection in order to identify different combinations of objects (quasar pairs, quasar+star alignments, lenses) that are blended into extended objects by the survey pipelines (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S14\">5</a>).</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>3.2. Choice of tree-based method</h3>\n<p>In the following sections, we describe the classification algorithm and calibration strategy that we use to build our catalogue, which was the end product of a large series of tests and experiments we carried out, also using different classification schemes, as detailed in the Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#APP1\">A</a>. We tested three different classifiers, all based on decision trees (Random Forests and two different Gradient Boosting approaches). In the end, we chose the CatBoost (<a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R35\">Dorogush et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR96\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R96\">Prokhorenkova et al. 2018</a>) scheme, out of the two Gradient Boosting (GB, <a name=\"InR42\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R42\">Friedman 2000</a>) ensemble algorithms that we tested, because it provided the best performance during the training process, which is described below.</p>\n<p>In general, GB is an ensemble algorithm that constructs a learner by fitting in an iterative way the gradients of the prediction residuals from the previously constructed <i>weak</i> learners, typically decision trees (gradient boosting decision trees (GBDTs)). In particular, CatBoost is a novel, fast, scalable, high-performance open-source GBDT library<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN9\">5</a></sup>. Compared to other GBDT algorithms, CatBoost has the advantage of using Ordered Boosting (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R96\">Prokhorenkova et al. 2018</a>) to curb the overfitting problem, as we highlight in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#APP1\">A</a>. To our knowledge, this is the first application of the CatBoost algorithm to an astronomical task.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>3.3. Fine-tuning and learning process</h3>\n<p>In order to quantify the performance of a classifier, one needs to define a set of validation data and the type of learning with respect to the training-to-validation division. We therefore split the validation into two groups: out-of-fold (OOF) and hold-out. The hold-out sample consists of a random subsample of the initial training data which will be used only for the final performance quantification. The remaining part of the initial sample is used to train the classifiers with a <i>k</i>-fold cross-validation procedure. This is a common method to train classifiers and directly compare classification algorithms. Briefly, one divides the training sample into <i>k</i> randomly partitioned disjoint equal parts. The classification algorithm then trains on <i>k</i>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;1 parts and the remaining one is used as validating data. This process is repeated <i>k</i> times, each time using one of the <i>k</i> disjoint subsamples as validating data and obtaining a prediction from it. The combination of these <i>k</i> predictions forms the so-called OOF sample. Similarly, to obtain the prediction on the new data, the <i>k</i> predictions from each of the fold models are averaged together. A schematic view of the learning process is visualized in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F2\">2</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2.</span></a><p>Schematic view of the learning via ten-fold cross validation procedure and validation with the OOF and the hold-out samples drawn from the initial training sample.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>Starting from the SDSS &#215; KiDS sample of 121 376 sources, we randomly selected 20% of it as hold-out sample and use the remaining 80% as OOF training sample in the cross-validation process<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN10\">6</a></sup>. We stress that among the classifiers that we tested, CatBoost returned the best performance both on the hold-out and OOF samples.</p>\n<p>Before training can take place, the classifier has a list of <i>hyper</i>-parameters that have to be tuned to reach the highest possible classification quality. This is true for each of the different classifiers that we tested. For this purpose, we performed an optimal hyperparameter search on 60% of the initial training sample via three-fold cross-validation with a &#8220;BayesSearch&#8221; for CatBoost<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN11\">7</a></sup>.</p>\n<p>While tuning the wide range of hyperparameters for CatBoost, we noticed that the most influential ones were the <tt>max_depth</tt> and the <tt>early_stopping</tt> parameters. We selected max_depth&#8198;&#8196;=&#8196;&#8198;8 and early_stopping&#8198;&#8196;=&#8196;&#8198;150 after BayesSearch, with a maximum number of trees of 3500.</p>\n<p>Moreover, we applied a weighting criterion to the loss function for the CatBoost model to further decrease the contaminants by stars in the extragalactic objects catalogue (see Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S19\">A.1</a> for more details).</p>\n<p>After this hyperparameter fine-tuning, we finally trained CatBoost with the same training and validation data and with a ten-fold cross-validation (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F2\">2</a>). The result of the performance for the final CatBoost model (after the fine-tuning) is presented as confusion matrices in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F3\">3</a> for both the OOF sample (top) and the hold-out sample (bottom). Using the weighting for stars and galaxies, we saw a significant improvement in the purity of the quasar sample; in fact, by comparing the confusion matrices before and after re-weighting the loss function (see appendix), one can see that the rate of stars misclassified as quasars decreased from &#8776;0.60% to &#8776;0.30%. CatBoost lost only &lt; 1.50% of the quasars, thus only marginally decreasing the resulting completeness of this class.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3.</span></a><p>Confusion matrices for the final version of CatBoost, after weighting the loss function, performed on the OOF sample (<i>top panel</i>) and the hold-out sample (<i>bottom panel</i>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>3.4. Feature importance</h3>\n<p>Another notable result that we can get with CatBoost is the relative importance of each feature in the classification procedure. Feature importance, calculated with a decision tree, shows the frequency with which a certain feature occurs in the tree. In such a way, the higher frequency is directly related to the higher feature contribution to separate the sources, that is the importance of a given feature. An excellent example of this kind of analysis, together with a full description of the feature importance technique is presented in <a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R30\">D&#8217;Isanto et al. (2018)</a>. Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F4\">4</a> shows the ten most informative features for all of the CatBoost models, trained one by one via ten-fold cross-validation. Among these, the <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> is certainly the most important one, followed by <i>H</i>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>K</i><sub><i>s</i></sub>, <i>u</i>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>g</i>, <i>g</i>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>r</i>, and <i>J</i>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>K</i><sub><i>s</i></sub>. This is in perfect agreement with a number of results in the literature, for example using <i>u</i>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>g</i> and <i>g</i>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>r</i> colour diagram it is possible to separate low-redshift quasars from stars (<a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R2\">Abraham et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R23\">Carrasco et al. 2015</a>). These features, together with the stellarity, are also the most important ones in other ML-based classifiers (e.g. N19). Furthermore, quasars at <i>z</i>&#8198;&#8196;&#8776;&#8196;2.5 and <i>z</i>&#8198;&#8196;&#8776;&#8196;&#8198;5.6 may be recovered using the <i>K</i>-band information in the colour space (<a name=\"InR27\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R27\">Chiu et al. 2007</a>). Finally, it is well known and also intuitively easy to understand that morphological information (described here by the <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> feature) allows one to clearly select galaxies, dividing them from stars and quasars at least in the relatively bright magnitude range that we consider (<i>r</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;22<sup>m</sup>).</p>\n<p><a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4.</span></a><p>Importance of the ten most significant features, calculated with CatBoost in each of the ten folds. The dispersion of importance for each feature is represented by a horizontal tick at each bar.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>The upper panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F5\">5</a> shows the number of quasars, stars, and galaxies from the full initial training sample as a function of their <i>r</i>-band magnitude (in the AB reference system). The bottom panel of the same figure shows instead the percentage of objects that have been misclassified by our algorithm (contaminators). The maximum rate of star-contaminators per bin of <i>r</i>-band magnitude in the quasars catalogue is &#8804;0.6% and is expected at the faint end of the sample (<i>r</i>&#8196;&#8776;&#8196;22<sup>m</sup>). Instead, the stars misclassified as galaxies span over the full optical <i>r</i> magnitude range and do not exceed 0.1%.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5.</span></a><p><i>Upper panel</i>: histogram of the <i>r</i> magnitudes for the three classes of training sources (<i>top panel</i>). <i>Bottom panel</i>: rate at which stars are misclassified as quasars (red curve) or as galaxies (black curve) as a function of their <i>r</i> magnitude. The plot is produced for the full initial training sample.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>Finally, we checked the contamination rate against the S/N in the <i>u</i>-band, which is the noisiest one for KiDS, finding that the relative contamination of stars decreases at each magnitude bin by &#8764;2% when we only consider objects with <i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;100.</p>\n<p>For the input data, whose distribution in the feature space should be similar to that of the training set, we expect a contamination of 0.3% from stars and 0.1% from galaxies in the sample of quasars, and 0.1% from stars and 0.6% from quasars in the sample of galaxies. We therefore conclude that the algorithm is in principle able to correctly classify up to 97.5% of all the bright quasars, and up to 99.8% of the galaxies from the KiDS DR4 input catalogue. These estimations are ideal and do not necessarily reflect the real situation, because they are only based on the training sample, which is a much smaller and simpler sample than the full catalogue. A more realistic estimate of the quality of our extragalactic catalogue in terms of purity and completeness can be obtained using external data to validate the resulting sample of classified sources, as we do in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S10\">4</a>.</p>\n<p>We stress that, for our final scientific purpose of finding gravitationally lensed quasars, the most crucial point is to be able to clean any sample of stellar contaminants. It is indeed of fundamental importance to separate stars from quasars to as greater degree as possible, both being point-like sources.</p>\n<p>Since the KiDS DR4 input catalogue consists mostly of galaxies, there will be a non-negligible number of galaxies contaminating the quasars sample. However, as we explain in more detail in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S14\">5</a>, strong lenses can be classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt>, if the deflector gives a non-negligible contribution to the light and/or the multiple images of quasars are not deblended, or they can be identified as multiple quasars. In the first case, the whole system will result in one extended object whose colours are a mixture of typical galaxy and quasar colours. This is the main reason why we build and inspect a catalogue containing all the extragalactic sources (<tt>QSO</tt> + <tt>GALAXY</tt>) looking then for &#8220;Multiplets&#8221;: objects with nearby (within 5&#8243;) companions. In particular, we select sources classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt> with at least one nearby <tt>QSO</tt> companion, to find lenses belonging to former group, and sources classified as <tt>QSO</tt> with at least one <tt>QSO</tt> companion, to find lenses belonging to the latter group.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S10\"></a>4. The Bright EXtraGalactic Objects catalogue in KiDS DR4 (KiDS-BEXGO)</h2>\n<p>For each object in the KiDS DR4 input catalogue, the classifier returns three numbers representing the probability of belonging to each of the three classes of objects: <i>p</i><sub>STAR</sub>, <i>p</i><sub>GALAXY</sub>, <i>p</i><sub>QSO</sub>. In general, we assume that a source belongs to a given class when the probability of being in that class is the highest. With this simple assumption, starting from the input 9.6 million sources in the KiDS DR4 catalogue, we retrieved: 186 037 (2%) quasars, 3 716 137 (39%) stars, and 5 694 238 (59%) galaxies. Using a more severe threshold instead, namely considering that an object belongs to a class when the corresponding probability is &gt; 0.8, we obtain: 5 665 586 (59%) &#8220;sure&#8221; galaxies, 3 660 368 (38%) &#8220;sure&#8221; stars, and 145 653 (1.5%) &#8220;sure&#8221; quasars, plus 122 306 objects (1.3%) with &#8220;unsure&#8221; classification. We note that for the classification of objects in the final catalogue we stick to the original assumption that a source belongs to the class with the largest probability, without applying any further threshold, since &#8220;unsure&#8221; extragalactic sources (with <i>p</i><sub>GALAXY</sub>&#8196;&#8776;&#8196;<i>p</i><sub>QSO</sub>) could very well be good lens candidates where the deflector and the quasar images are blended and all give a contribution to the light of the system. However, since the levels of completeness and purity depend on the chosen probability, and different scientific cases might require different levels, we provide in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#T1\">1</a> the number of objects classified in each subsample for five different thresholds. Furthermore, Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F6\">6</a> shows the confusion matrices obtained for the OOF training sample for the four highest probability levels (0.8, 0.9, 0.95, 0.99) and the completeness rate as a function of the probability threshold for the three classes.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1.</span></a><p>Number of objects for each class using different probability threshold to define class belonging.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p><a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6.</span></a><p><i>Upper panel</i>: confusion matrices for the final version of CatBoost performed on the OOF sample using different thresholds of probability in the object classification (see text for more details). <i>Bottom panel</i>: completeness rate of the OOF sample as a function of the adopted probability threshold for each class.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=6&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>Finally, Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F7\">7</a> provides a visualization of the class distribution of the objects in the output catalogue. Each corner of the triangular density plot represents the maximum probability of belonging to a given class. Objects within the region delimited by dotted lines are &#8220;sure&#8221; according to the threshold given above (<i>p</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;0.8).</p>\n<p><a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7.</span></a><p>Density plot of the final distribution of sources among the classes in the output catalogue. The triangle corners show the maximum probability of belonging to a given family (right <tt>QSO</tt>, left <tt>GALAXY</tt>, up <tt>STAR</tt>), and colours indicate number of objects. Dashed lines correspond to the <i>p</i>&#8196;=&#8196;0.8 threshold.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=7&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S14\">5</a>, we only focus on the objects with <i>p</i><sub>QSO</sub>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;<i>p</i><sub>STAR</sub> or <i>p</i><sub>GALAXY</sub>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;<i>p</i><sub>STAR</sub> that form the KiDS-BEXGO catalogue used for the gravitational lens searches. Here, instead, we discuss three of the many possible validation procedures, for one or more classes of objects, performed using external data (from the <i>Gaia</i> astrometric survey, from the AllWISE infrared catalogue, and from the GAMA survey). Using an external dataset to validate catalogues obtained with ML techniques is a rather standard procedure, as already shown in for example <a name=\"InR60\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R60\">Khramtsov et al. (2018)</a>, where the PMA (<a name=\"InR8\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R8\">Akhmetov et al. 2017</a>) catalogue of proper motions was used to validate the purity of a sample of galaxies.</p>\n<p>Given the results presented in the tests below, together with predictions on the hold-out sample, we are confident that our ML classifier is able to minimize the stellar contamination in the BEXGO catalogue, which is the first, most crucial step when searching for gravitationally lensed quasars within very large catalogues.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S11\"></a>4.1. Astrometric validation with Gaia</h3>\n<p>The latest data release of <i>Gaia</i>, DR2 (<a name=\"InR43\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R43\">Gaia Collaboration 2018a</a>), measured five astrometric parameters (positions <i>&#945;</i>,&#8198;<i>&#948;</i>, proper motions <i>&#956;</i><sub><i>&#945;</i></sub>,&#8198;<i>&#956;</i><sub><i>&#948;</i></sub>, and parallaxes <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-eq1.gif\"></span>) for 1.3 billion sources, covering the whole celestial sphere up to <i>G</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;21<sup>m</sup><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN12\">8</a></sup>. The systematical errors in <i>Gaia</i> DR2, estimated with &#8776;500&#8198;000 quasars, do not exceed 0.03 mas (<a name=\"InR44\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R44\">Gaia Collaboration 2018b</a>). Thus, the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 provides an excellent means to test the purity of our catalogue, especially for quasars.</p>\n<p>One of the main observational properties of quasars that can be used to validate the sample of candidates classified as such is the fact that they have proper motions of only a few micro-arcseconds since they very distant sources (<a name=\"InR12\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R12\">Bachchan et al. 2016</a>).</p>\n<p>We cross-matched the KiDS DR4 sample of 9.5 million classified sources with the <i>Gaia</i> DR2 catalogue using a <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-eq2.gif\"></span> radius, and retrieved a sample of sources with defined astrometric parameters, of which 52 636 were classified as <tt>QSO</tt>, 2 369 414 were classified as <tt>STAR</tt>, and 25 346 &#8211; as <tt>GALAXY</tt>. We then checked the proper motions and parallaxes of all the objects classified as quasars and with a match in <i>Gaia</i> to test the assumption that quasars are indeed zero-proper-motion and zero-parallax sources within the systematic errors. The results of this test are shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F8\">8</a>. The behaviour of the proper-motion components is consistent with the estimated contamination of stars within the quasar subsample of the KiDS DR4 catalogue (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F5\">5</a>). In fact, at the faintest magnitudes (<i>G</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;20.5<sup>m</sup>), the proper-motion components deviate strongly due to larger contamination from stars. At very bright magnitudes (<i>G</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;17.5<sup>m</sup>), the standard deviation of the mean of the proper motions and parallaxes is also large, but this is due to a relatively small amount of sources in this magnitude bin rather than to star contamination. It is also important to note that the parallax (right plot of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F8\">8</a>) is biased for the sample of extragalactic sources towards the value of &#8722;0.029 mas reported in <a name=\"InR76\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R76\">Lindegren et al. (2018)</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8.</span></a><p>Median right ascension (green curve, <i>left</i>) and declination (black curve, <i>left</i>) of the proper motion components, and parallax (red curve, <i>right</i>) for the KiDS DR4 <tt>QSO</tt> sample as a function of the <i>Gaia</i><i>G</i> magnitude. The coloured areas represent the standard deviation of the mean <i>&#963;</i>/<i>N</i>, where <i>&#963;</i> is the standard deviation and <i>N</i> is the number of quasars in each bin. The black horizontal line in the <i>right plot</i> represents the parallax zero-point (equals to &#8722;0.029 mas, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R76\">Lindegren et al. 2018</a>).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>Given the mean, median, and standard deviation of the proper motion components and of the parallax of the astrometric parameters reported in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#T2\">2</a>, we can conclude that the sample of KiDS DR4 quasars mainly consists of motionless sources. A more detailed astrometric analysis, providing a more quantitative estimation of the rate of contaminating stars, cannot be produced without accurate modelling and the involvement of other external datasets, which goes beyond the purposes of this paper.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2.</span></a><p>Basic statistics of the astrometric parameters of all the objects in the KiDS output catalogue classified as quasars and with a match in <i>Gaia</i> DR2.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p>To assess the purity of the galaxy sample, we use the very simple argument that, by construction, <i>Gaia</i> should contain no galaxies at all (<a name=\"InR100\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R100\">Robin et al. 2012</a>). Thus none of the objects with high <i>p</i><sub>GALAXY</sub> should have a match in <i>Gaia</i> DR2. This is, of course, only a rough approximation since there might be a number of galaxies that <i>Gaia</i> still measures, such as for example objects with bright cores. From the cross-match with <i>Gaia</i>, we find &#8776;25 000 objects classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt>. We note that among these only 1784 objects have <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> &gt; 0.5, and thus can be point-like sources in KiDS, misclassified by our algorithm, or very compact galaxies below the KiDS resolution.</p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F9\">9</a> we show the distribution of the <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> parameter for each class of objects in the full KiDS DR4 catalogue. Assuming that galaxies are all extended objects, we would expect to find in KiDS no objects classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt> with <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> &gt; 0.5. However, there are objects that are point-like according to their <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> value but that have been classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt> by our algorithm on the basis of their colours. The number of point-like galaxies from Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F9\">9</a> is larger than a couple of thousand, as predicted by the cross-match with <i>Gaia</i>. This slight disagreement might be explained by the better resolution of <i>Gaia</i> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R68\">Krone-Martins et al. 2018</a>): these sources might be seen as point-like in KiDS, but are extended and thus not identified in <i>Gaia</i>. Despite this, the majority of <tt>GALAXY</tt> sources with a <i>Gaia</i> match are indeed extended objects in KiDS, or sources near to a bright star. This was directly verified on a random sample of &#8776;5000 objects via the SDSS DR14 Navigate Tool<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN13\">9</a></sup>, and then also by checking the KiDS <i>r</i>-band images, finding bright features (e.g. cores, regions in arms, etc.) for most of the sources that could be resolved only for galaxies with significant angular size.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9.</span></a><p>Distribution of the <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> parameter for the sources classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt> (black), <tt>QSO</tt> (red), or <tt>STARS</tt> (blue).</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>4.2. Validation of galaxies with GAMA</h3>\n<p>To validate the pureness and completeness of the subsample of galaxies within the BEXGO catalogue, we cross-matched it with spectroscopically confirmed galaxies from the Galaxy And Mass Assembly Survey Data Release 3 (GAMA DR3, <a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R14\">Baldry et al. 2018</a>). In particular, following the suggestions given on the GAMA website, we retrieved all the objects<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN14\">10</a></sup> with redshifts <i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;0.05 and with a high &#8220;normalised&#8221; redshift quality (<i>n</i><i>Q</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;1). We matched these &#8776;208<i>k</i> sources with our final catalogue of classified objects from KiDS, finding 105 334 systems in common. Among these, 105 018 were indeed classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt> from CatBoost and 104 970 have a <i>p</i><sub>GALAXY</sub>&#8196;&#8805;&#8196;0.8. Thus, only 0.3% of the common objects have been misclassified (123 as <tt>STARS</tt> and 181 <tt>QSO</tt>). Although we are aware that this test is not definitive and that it is not straightforward to directly translate the relative number of contaminants into a percentage of pureness of the final galaxy catalogue, it shows that, at least for this small but representative sample of galaxies, our CatBoost classifiers perform well.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>4.3. Validation of quasars with mid-infrared data from WISE</h3>\n<p>Mid-infrared (MIR) colours are a very effective way to separate quasars from stars and passive galaxies, since while the latter two show approximately zero MIR colours, quasars emit strongly in these bands (<a name=\"InR40\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R40\">Elvis et al. 1994</a>; <a name=\"InR115\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R115\">Stern et al. 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR11\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R11\">Assef et al. 2013</a>). As largely demonstrated by a number of published works, including Paper I, it is possible to separate quasars from stars and galaxies using a combination of infrared colour and magnitudes cuts (e.g. the two-colour criteria of <a name=\"InR72\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R72\">Lacy et al. 2004</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R115\">Stern et al. 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R34\">Donley et al. 2012</a> with <i>Spitzer</i><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN15\">11</a></sup> data; the two-colour criteria in <a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R55\">Jarrett et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR80\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R80\">Mateos et al. 2012</a>; or the one-colour criteria of <a name=\"InR116\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R116\">Stern et al. 2012</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R11\">Assef et al. 2013</a>). We note that in general it is harder to validate the purity of galaxies in the same way since stars overlap with (non-active) galaxies in this dimension (see e.g. Fig. 12 in <a name=\"InR127\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R127\">Wright et al. 2010</a>).</p>\n<p>Here, we decided to use the single infrared colour cut [3.6] <i>&#956;</i>m &#8722; [4.5] <i>&#956;</i>m &gt; 0.8 proposed by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R116\">Stern et al. (2012)</a> using data from the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer, WISE (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R127\">Wright et al. 2010</a>), the NASA space mission that aims at mapping the whole sky in four MIR bands: <i>W</i>1, <i>W</i>2, <i>W</i>3, <i>W</i>4 (3.6, 4.5, 12 and 22 <i>&#956;</i>m respectively). This criterion can separate quasars from stars and galaxies with a purity of &#8776;95%, but allows one to select systems only up to <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8776;&#8196;3.5 (<a name=\"InR48\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R48\">Guo et al. 2018</a>). Moreover, we caution the reader that a sample selected with this criterion can be contaminated by brown dwarfs which have similar colours. The more elaborate two-colour criterion of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R80\">Mateos et al. (2012)</a> allows one to reduce this contamination, but it requires reliable measurements in the <i>W</i>3 band, which would significantly decreases the total number of matched sources in our case.</p>\n<p>Finally, we wish to clarify that in this paper the WISE data are only used as validation for the quasar catalogue but not for the lens search. As a matter of fact, the bottle-neck of the search for gravitationally lenses performed in Paper I was indeed the overly severe WISE colour pre-selection. In case the lens and the source are blended in WISE and the deflector gives a large contribution to the light, the colours of this effective source may no longer be quasar-like and may move indeed toward lower <i>W</i>1&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>W</i>2 values. These objects were not retained in our previous study. Here we rely on a more solid and trustworthy way to classify objects, our ML-based classifier, and thus we do not need to apply any cut, nor do we need to require a match with WISE to build our candidates list.</p>\n<p>We cross-matched the SDSS training sample as well as the catalogue of all the classified objects with the AllWISE (<a name=\"InR29\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R29\">Cutri et al. 2013</a>) data release using a <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-eq4.gif\"></span> radius. The resulting sample consists of 114 773 quasars, 3 289 858 galaxies, and 2 020 768 stars for the classified objects and of 8 879 quasars, 78 816 galaxies, and 13 249 stars for the SDSS &#215; KiDS training sample.</p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F10\">10</a> shows the histograms of the distribution of the <i>W</i>1&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>W</i>2 colour for the KIDS DR4 objects classified in the three classes (left panels), and for the corresponding training sample (right panel), colour coded by their classification family: red for <tt>QSO</tt>, black for <tt>GALAXY</tt>, and blue for <tt>STARS</tt>. In general, the distribution of the full catalogue shows a similar distribution to that of the training sample, with the peak of the <tt>QSO</tt> subsample shifted toward larger <i>W</i>1&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>W</i>2 values (<i>W</i>1&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>W</i>2&#8196;&gt; &#8196;0.8), as expected. We note however that the distributions of the full catalogue are much broader than the distributions of the corresponding training sample, especially towards larger <i>W</i>1&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>W</i>2 values, both in negative and in positive. This is particularly true for the <tt>GALAXY</tt> and <tt>STAR</tt> classes. This might indicate a lower purity for these families and consequently a larger contamination level in the <tt>QSO</tt> family, or a lack in the training sample of particular classes of objects (e.g. active galaxies). As we show in the previous section, the purity of the objects classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt> seems to be relatively high. Therefore, we speculate that one of the reasons for the slight disagreement between the distribution of galaxies from the training sample and from the output BEXGO catalogue in the <i>W</i>1&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>W</i>2 space might simply arise from the fact that the SDSS galaxies are generally more luminous than the KiDS ones.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10.</span></a><p><i>Left panel</i>: distribution of the <i>W</i>1&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>W</i>2 colour for the classified KiDS DR4, colour coded according to their classification family (red for <tt>QSO</tt>, black for <tt>GALAXY</tt>, blue for <tt>STAR</tt>). <i>Right panel</i>: distribution of the <i>W</i>1&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>W</i>2 colour for the train samples. A fair agreement can be found between corresponding classes, although the distribution for the full catalogues is generally broader than that of the training samples. In both panels, the peak of the <tt>QSO</tt> distribution is shifted towards larger <i>W</i>1&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>W</i>2 with respect to the <tt>GALAXY</tt> and <tt>STARS</tt>, as expected.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=10&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>More and deeper investigations will be performed into purity and completeness in the forthcoming papers of the KiDS-SQuaD series. Nevertheless, we are confident that our automatic classifier allows us to obtain a catalogue of quasars and galaxies with very little stellar contamination. In fact, as we show in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S14\">5</a>, the contamination is much less than that obtained in Paper I, where we rely on simple and manual optical and infrared colour cuts. We stress again that our final goal has been to create an automatic and effective method to build a catalogue of extragalactic objects with the smallest possible contamination from stars. This is the first necessary step in searching for strong gravitationally lensed quasars. We believe that these three validation steps with external data demonstrate that we have succeeded in our goal and therefore can now use the newly created catalogue to search for lens candidates.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S14\"></a>5. Searching for gravitationally lensed quasars</h2>\n<p>Strong gravitationally lensed quasars are valuable but very rare objects that can provide direct and purely gravitational probes of cosmology and extragalactic astrophysics. Generally speaking, we can separate lensed quasars into three families: (i) systems where the quasar images dominate (mainly low-separation couples/quadruplets with a faint deflector in between), (ii) objects where the deflector is a bright, usually red, massive galaxy that dominates the light budget of the system, and finally (iii) systems where both lens and source give a non-negligible contribution to the light. In the last two cases, CatBoost will most probably return multiple matches, of which at least one will be classified as extended (<tt>GALAXY</tt>), while in the former one it will classify them as multiple <tt>QSO</tt>. However, we note that in cases where the separation between the quasar components is too small, the objects might not be resolved in the KiDS catalogue, and thus might result in a single match from our algorithm. Indeed, most of the known low-separation gravitationally lensed quasars discovered in the SDSS are identified as &#8220;single&#8221; galaxies (only in a few cases as a single quasar), since the poor resolution does not allow the multiple components to be deblended. Of course, the better image resolution of KiDS helps in this case, but some lenses with very low separation are blended also in KiDS. This is why it is of crucial importance to have a catalogue of extragalactic objects that is as clean from stellar contamination as possible and as complete and efficient as possible in selecting and classifying galaxies and quasars.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S15\"></a>5.1. Recovery of known lens systems</h3>\n<p>To demonstrate our statement that lensed quasars are not always classified as (multiples, nearby) <tt>QSO</tt> by ML-based algorithms that work in a magnitude-colour space, and at the same time to highlight the importance of having an extragalactic catalogue, we carried out a test on the recovery of known lenses, as already done in Paper I.</p>\n<p>We started from the same list of &#8776;260 confirmed lensed quasars that we used in Paper I and updated it with new systems recently discovered in wide-sky surveys (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R6\">Agnello et al. 2018a</a>,<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R7\">b</a>; <a name=\"InR89\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R89\">Ostrovski et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R10\">Anguita et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR78\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R78\">Lemon et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR114\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R114\">Spiniello et al. 2019</a>). The cross-match between the full KIDS DR4 catalogue of objects with <i>r</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;22<sup>m</sup> and the list of known lensed quasars (288 systems) gave us 17 known lenses. All of them have been retrieved in the KiDS-BEXGO catalogue, 10 classified as <tt>QSO</tt> and 7 as <tt>GALAXY</tt> (one of them with a <i>p</i><sub>QSO</sub>&#8196;&#8776;&#8196;0.45). In 8 cases the lenses returned multiple matches (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#S16\">5.2</a>). These 17 known lenses are reported in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#T3\">3</a>, together with the probability of belonging to each class. We do not explicitly report their right ascensions and declinations in separate columns because their IDs already contain the J2000 coordinates in the usual &#8220;hhmmss.ss &#177; ddmmss.ss&#8221; format.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3.</span></a><p>Known lenses in the KIDS DR4 footprint.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p>Based on this simple and qualitative test, it appears clear that selecting only quasars would allow one to find only lens systems where the contribution to the light from the quasars is much larger than the contribution of the deflector. Selecting only <tt>QSO</tt> we would retrieve roughly 65% of the known lensed quasar population &#8211; 11 out of 17 systems.</p>\n<p>Finally, although this goes beyond the scope of this paper, we note that another important advantage of having an extragalactic source catalogue (rather than one containing only quasars) is that it offers the possibility to search for galaxy&#8211;galaxy gravitational lenses. This type of gravitationally lensed object allows the detailed investigation of mass distribution in massive galaxies up to <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;1, especially when combined with dynamics (<a name=\"InR66\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R66\">Koopmans et al. 2006</a>, <a name=\"InR67\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R67\">2009</a>; <a name=\"InR111\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R111\">Spiniello et al. 2011</a>, <a name=\"InR112\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R112\">2015</a>). Morphological and photometric criteria can be used to find this kind of lens: one should look for red extended objects (<tt>GALAXY</tt> with red colours) with the presence of blue extended objects (<tt>GALAXY</tt> with blue colours) within small circular apertures. We will work in this direction in a forthcoming paper, possibly using automatic ML-based routines (e.g. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R92\">Petrillo et al. 2017</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R93\">2019a</a>,<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R94\">b</a>) and already available catalogues of luminous red galaxies in the Kilo Degree Survey (e.g. <a name=\"InR122\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R122\">Vakili et al. 2019</a>).</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S16\"></a>5.2. Looking for Multiplets</h3>\n<p>Starting from the KiDS-BEXGO catalogue of 5 880 276 objects, we retrieve only systems belonging to the following distinct groups:</p>\n<p>(1) &#8220;<tt>QSO</tt>-Multiplets&#8221;: sources classified as <tt>QSO</tt> and with at least one nearby <tt>QSO</tt> companion (within a 5&#8243; circular aperture radius) with similar colours, and (2) &#8220;<tt>GALAXY</tt>-Multiplets&#8221;: sources classified as <tt>GALAXY</tt> and surrounded by at least one object classified as <tt>QSO</tt> within a 5&#8243; circular aperture radius<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN16\">12</a></sup>.</p>\n<p>This simple procedure allowed us to obtain 347 unique objects for the first group and 611 unique objects for the second. These 958 objects were then visually inspected independently by four researchers in our team that also graded them from &#8220;0&#8221; to &#8220;4&#8221;, with &#8220;4&#8221; being a &#8220;sure&#8221; lens. Among these, some where already known lenses, some are probably binary quasars, and some are simply contaminants appearing as close-by companions because of sky projection. Nevertheless, we found many very promising lens candidates, objects that at least two people graded with a score higher than or equal to &#8220;2&#8221;. We present the 12 candidates with mean grade &#8805;2.5 in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#T4\">4</a> (divided into the two types of Multiplets). We publicly release their coordinates to facilitate spectroscopic follow-up, which is the last necessary step for unambiguous confirmation.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 4.</span></a><p>Most reliable gravitationally lensed quasar candidates found with the &#8220;Multiplets&#8221; method described in the text.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p>The <i>g</i><i>r</i><i>i</i>-combined KiDS cutouts of these 12 candidates are shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#F11\">11</a>. The first two rows show candidates belonging to the <tt>GALAXY</tt>-Multiplets family while the bottom row shows <tt>QSO</tt>-Multiplets candidates. In the former group, the deflector gives a much larger contribution to the light, as can be clearly seen from the images. KiDSJ0008&#8722;3237 seems to be a very reliable galaxy&#8211;galaxy candidate, while KiDSJ0215&#8722;2909, definitively among the most promising objects, might be a fold-quadruplet similar to the one recently found in the VST-ATLAS Survey, WISE 025942.9&#8722;163543 (<a name=\"InR106\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R106\">Schechter et al. 2018</a>) and very useful for cosmography studies (time-delay measurement of <i>H</i><sub>0</sub>; see e.g. &#8220;The H0 Lenses in COSMOGRAIL&#8217;s Wellspring&#8221;<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN17\">13</a></sup> results).</p>\n<p><a name=\"F11\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11.</span></a><p>12 best candidates, both of <tt>GALAXY</tt>-Multiplets type (<i>first two rows</i>) and of <tt>QSO</tt>-Multiplets type (<i>bottom row</i>). The cutouts show <i>g</i><i>r</i><i>i</i> combined KiDS images of 10&#8243;&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10&#8243; in size. The coordinates of the candidates are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#T4\">4</a>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=11&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936006\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>We note that of the 17 known lenses, only 8 have been selected as Multiplets (2 as <tt>QSO</tt>-Multiplets and 6 as <tt>GALAXY</tt>-Multiplets). The other 9 systems have not been deblended in the KiDS catalogue, and thus only have one single match in our classification scheme. These numbers are perfectly in line with the results obtained in Paper I where we found that the &#8220;Multiplets&#8221; method alone allowed the recovery of &#8764;40% of the known lenses. In a forthcoming paper of this series fully dedicated to the lens search, we will perform a more careful candidate selection, also based on improved colour and magnitude criteria, to select objects with similar colours and applying the Blue and Red Offsets of Quasars and Extragalactic Sources (BaROQuES) scripts to the full BEXGO catalogue, which were already successful tested in Paper I.</p>\n<p>We finally note that we re-discovered a very promising quadruplet: KIDS0239&#8722;3211 that was presented in an AAS research note (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R109\">Sergeyev et al. 2018</a>) and was found by the first application of our ML-based classifier<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN18\">14</a></sup>. The same system was first detected by <a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R49\">Hartley et al. (2017)</a> using image-based Support Vector Machine classifier and then by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R94\">Petrillo et al. (2019b)</a> using convolutional neural networks; but since they did not release the coordinates in their paper, we re-discover it in a completely independent way.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>5.3. Comparison with Paper I</h3>\n<p>We cross-match the list of all the lens candidates found in Paper I with the BEXGO catalogue. We find that among the 210 objects we found in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R113\">Spiniello et al. (2018)</a>, 148 are recovered in the extragalactic objects catalogue (&#8776;45% classified as <tt>QSO</tt> and &#8776;55% as <tt>GALAXY</tt>) and 66 are also selected as Multiplets. Of the 62 remaining objects, 33 have <i>r</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;22<sup>m</sup> and therefore were discarded at the input catalogue creation stage, and 29 were classified as <tt>STAR</tt> by CatBoost; these 29 stars indeed also have a match in <i>Gaia</i>, and all of them have non-negligible proper motions and parallaxes. Finally, among the DR3 candidates that were not found in the DR4 KiDS-BEXGO, four were spectroscopically followed-up and turned out to be stars<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#FN19\">15</a></sup>. These numbers nicely demonstrate that the employment of the ML-based classifier further helps in decreasing the risk of stellar contamination within gravitationally lensed quasar candidates.</p>\n<p>Of the seven known lenses that we recovered in Paper I, six are again recovered. We only lose the nearly identical quasar (NIQ) couple QJ0240&#8722;343 (<a name=\"InR120\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R120\">Tinney 1995</a>; <a name=\"InR121\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R121\">Tinney et al. 1997</a>) behind the Fornax dwarf spheroidal galaxy, because it has <i>r</i> magnitude of <i>r</i>&#8196;=&#8196;22.17<sup>m</sup> and therefore did not satisfy our initial conditions.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S18\"></a>6. Results and conclusions</h2>\n<p>In this second paper of the KiDS-SQuaD project we present a new ML-based classifier to identify extragalactic objects in a search for lensed quasars within the KiDS DR4 data. The technique adopted in this paper has become relatively standard in the extragalactic community to classify objects in multi-band photometric surveys (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R45\">Gieseke et al. 2011</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R62\">Kov&#225;cs &amp; Szapudi 2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R21\">Brescia et al. 2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R23\">Carrasco et al. 2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R91\">Peters et al. 2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R63\">Krakowski et al. 2016</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R64\">2018</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R124\">Viquar et al. 2018</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R59\">Khramtsov &amp; Akhmetov 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R16\">Barrientos et al. 2018</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R85\">Nolte et al. 2019</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R13\">Bai et al. 2019</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R84\">Nakoneczny et al. 2019</a>), which provide a very large amount of data.</p>\n<p>A similar approach has also been already tested on the Kilo Degree Survey by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R84\">Nakoneczny et al. (2019)</a>, who presented a ML-based pipeline to classify objects into three classes (stars, galaxies and quasars) and successfully applied it to the KiDS DR3 (<a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R32\">de Jong et al. 2017</a>). Our work, although extending from their findings, has been developed within a different framework, i.e. the search for lensed quasars, and it differs from N19 in many aspects, from the assumption that quasars are point-like sources to the cleaning procedure, optimization, and fine-tuning aimed at minimizing stellar contamination in the catalogue of extragalactic objects. Finally, here we also add infrared data, using deep photometry in nine bands (instead of four), which further helps to isolate stars.</p>\n<p>Here we provide a general summary of the archived results of this paper, highlighting the main main steps that we undertook and the results that we achieved.</p>\n<p>We used the large potential of ML methods on broad optical&#8211;infrared photometric data from the KiDS DR4 survey. We identified the CatBoost ad the best possible classifiers for our purposes, comparing and quantifying the performance of some of the most used classifiers based on decision trees on the same training sample. The result of this direct comparison is presented in Appendix <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#APP1\">A</a>. Moreover, we performed ad-hoc customization and fine-tuning of the parameters of CatBoost, to reach the required levels of purity and completeness and to avoid overfitting problems.</p>\n<p>We used a set of 121 376 spectroscopic confirmed objects from the SDSS DR14, after applying a careful cleaning procedure and also visually inspecting the ambiguous cases when necessary. We splitted the training dataset into hold-out and out-of-fold parts, to asses the performance (in terms of completeness and purity) of the CatBoost algorithm. We then defined (and solved) a three-class problem (<tt>STAR</tt>, <tt>GALAXY</tt>, <tt>QSO</tt>), working with a simple basic assumption made for the classification: quasars and stars are point-like sources, while galaxies are extended. We therefore used the <tt>CLASS_STAR</tt> parameter &#8211; a &#8220;stellarity&#8221; index from the KiDS catalogue &#8211; which turned out to be the most important feature in our classification algorithm (as in N19), together with optical and infrared colours.</p>\n<p>We applied CatBoost on all the data from KiDS DR4 with magnitude brighter than <i>r</i>&#8196;=&#8196;22<sup>m</sup> and reliable photometry measured in each of the nine bands. For each input source, the classifier calculated the probability of belonging to the three different classes of objects: <i>p</i><sub>STAR</sub>, <i>p</i><sub>GALAXY</sub>, <i>p</i><sub>QSO</sub>. We assumed that a source belongs to a given class when the probability of being in that class is the highest but we also studied the variation in completeness and purity as a function of the probability threshold used to assign an object to a given class.</p>\n<p>We collected all the objects that were not classified as stars, building the KiDS-BEXGO catalogue, which we then validated using external data (<i>Gaia</i> DR2, AllWISE and GAMA).</p>\n<p>We firstly showed the potential of the KiDS-BEXGO catalogue in the gravitationally lensed quasar search, with a simple test on the recovery of known, confirmed lenses. We proved, in this way, that our method of selecting extragalactic sources (not only quasars) is a necessary condition to discover as many new systems as possible. Secondly, we used the KiDS-BEXGO catalogue to search for new, undiscovered gravitationally lensed quasars, looking for objects with nearby companions and obtained a list of 958 &#8220;Multiplets&#8221; (347 <tt>QSO</tt> and 611 <tt>GALAXY</tt>) that we visually inspected. We found 12 very reliable lens candidates, for which we release coordinates and show KiDS <i>g</i><i>r</i><i>i</i>-combined images.</p>\n<p>Finally, we showed the improvement in terms of stellar contamination of the final list of candidates that we obtain with respect to what was obtained in Paper I.</p>\n<p>In this paper we focussed on the ML classifier and on building the catalogue of bright extragalactic objects, which can be useful for a broad series of scientific goals, but at the same time we highlighted the need for different methods to search for lens candidates within the catalogue (e.g. the BaROQuES) and direct image analysis (DIA). These methods will be investigated and applied to BEXGO in Paper III, already in preparation (Sergeyev et al., in prep.), where we will present a systematic and automated way to select reliable candidates from the KiDS-BEXGO catalogue, as well as the first results from the ongoing spectroscopic follow-up campaigns. In particular, we will apply the BaROQuES scripts to our catalogue and will also exploit the full potential of the DIA (see Paper I for more details) to get precise astrometry and fit the photometry of our most reliable candidates. Finally, in the future, we aim to improve the classification model, working in a larger, more complex feature space, and to develop a more detailed classification scheme, for example splitting the classification of galaxies into late and early types, given that massive early types are more likely acting as deflectors due to the fact that on average they are more massive.</p>\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN5\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">SDSS DR14 is the second release of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey IV phase (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R18\">Blanton et al. 2017</a>) and it includes data from all previous SDSS data releases.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN6\"></a><sup>2</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">We note that this assumption was not made in N19 which included in the <tt>QSO</tt> training sample the relatively near (<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;0.2) AGNs and visible host galaxies.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN7\"></a><sup>3</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">As a matter of fact, inspecting the misclassified data from SDSS we found three interesting lensed quasar candidates that we selected for spectroscopic follow up. If confirmed, the system will be presented in a forthcoming publication.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN8\"></a><sup>4</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">We used the Navigate SDSS visual tool (<a href=\"http://skyserver.sdss.org/dr14/en/tools/chart/navi.aspx\" target=\"_blank\">http://skyserver.sdss.org/dr14/en/tools/chart/navi.aspx</a>) to inspect misclassified sources.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN9\"></a><sup>5</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://catboost.ai/\" target=\"_blank\">https://catboost.ai/</a>, developed by Yandex researchers and engineers <a href=\"https://yandex.com/company/\" target=\"_blank\">https://yandex.com/company/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN10\"></a><sup>6</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">The hold-out and OOF samples are kept fixed for all the various algorithms that we tested (see Appendix).</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN11\"></a><sup>7</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Same for XGBoost, while we use a &#8220;GridSearch&#8221; method for RF.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN12\"></a><sup>8</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">This limit corresponds to <i>r</i>&#8196;&#8776;&#8196;21<sup>m</sup> for quasars at <i>z</i>&#8196;&#8804;&#8196;3, (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R95\">Proft &amp; Wambsganss 2015</a>).</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN13\"></a><sup>9</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"http://skyserver.sdss.org/dr14/en/tools/chart/navi.aspx\" target=\"_blank\">http://skyserver.sdss.org/dr14/en/tools/chart/navi.aspx</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN14\"></a><sup>10</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Also the ones observed by other surveys, i.e. we queried the table &#8220;SpecAll&#8221;.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN15\"></a><sup>11</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2019/12/aa36006-19/aa36006-19.html#R126\">Werner et al. (2004)</a>.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN16\"></a><sup>12</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">The choice of a 5&#8243; circular aperture radius is motivated by the average separation of all the known lenses.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN17\"></a><sup>13</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"http://www.h0licow.org\" target=\"_blank\">www.h0licow.org</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN18\"></a><sup>14</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">We used in that case a Random Forests classifier, trained with spectroscopically confirmed objects from SDSS DR14.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN19\"></a><sup>15</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">We have already started a spectroscopic follow-up campaign using different facilities (e.g. the NTT at La Silla, the SALT at Suthernland Observatory, the LBT at Mt. Graham). The detailed results will be presented in forthcoming dedicated papers.</p>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ack\"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>\n<p>The authors wish to thank Maciej Bilicki for the interesting discussion and the very constructive comments that helped in improving the final manuscript. GAMA is funded by the STFC (UK), the ARC (Australia), the AAO, and the participating institutions. The GAMA website is <a href=\"http://www.gama-survey.org/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.gama-survey.org/</a></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ref\"></a>References</h2>\n    <div id=\"content\">\n        <ol class=\"references\">\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R1\"></a>Abolfathi, B., Aguado, D., Aguilar, G., et al. 2018, ApJS, 235, 42\n\n                \n                                                            <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/#abs/2018ApJS..235...42A/abstract\">\n                                                    [NASA ADS]\n                                                </a>\n                                                                                <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.3847/1538-4365/aa9e8a\">\n                                                    [CrossRef]\n                                                </a>\n                                    \n                \n                                    <a href=\"https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?author=Abolfathi%2C+B.%2C+Aguado%2C+D.+S.%2C+Aguilar%2C+G.&journal=ApJS&volume=235&issue=2&pages=42&publication_year=2018&issn=1538-4365\">[Google&nbsp;Scholar]</a>\n                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R2\"></a>Abraham, S., Philip, N., Kembhavi, A., Wadadekar, Y.                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n                    <li>\n                <a name=\"R110\"></a>Sluse, D., Schmidt, R., Courbin, F., et al. 2011, A&amp;A, 528, A100\n\n                \n                                                            <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/#abs/2011A&A...528A.100S/abstract\">\n                                                    [NASA ADS]\n                                                </a>\n                                                                                <a target=\"link_edps\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201016110\">\n                                                    [CrossRef]\n                                                </a>\n                                                                                <a target=\"link_edps\" </a>\n                                    \n                \n                                    <a                \n                \n                 <span class=\"Z3988\" title=\"\">\n                                    </span>\n\n                \n                            </li>\n
